content_of_the_post: This list got me thinking about the meaning of these objectives for me. ⁠⁠An 𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗲𝗽𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗲𝘂𝗿'𝘀 𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗱 means taking charge and being responsible for everything that goes down. ⁠⁠It means being open to different perspectives and possibilities, rather than just saying no. ⁠⁠It means prioritizing action over planning and always looking to learn more. ⁠⁠An 𝗮𝘁𝗵𝗹𝗲𝘁𝗲'𝘀 𝗯𝗼𝗱𝘆 means eating healthy and working out daily. ⁠⁠It means going to bed early and getting a solid 8 hours of sleep. ⁠⁠It means taking time to relax and clear your mind through stretching and meditation, and even trying out fasting and cold exposure. ⁠⁠An 𝗮𝗿𝘁𝗶𝘀𝘁'𝘀 𝘀𝗼𝘂𝗹 means being open to new experiences and finding ways to tap into your creativity. ⁠⁠It means trusting your gut, even if you can't put it into words. ⁠⁠It means being authentic.⁠👉 What do they mean to you?⁠🧩
rewrited_content:
{'Professional and Friendly Tone': "
Reflecting on this list made me realize what these goals truly mean to me. 

In my life, having an 𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗲𝗽𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗲𝘂𝗿'𝘀 𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗱 means taking control and being accountable for everything that happens. 

It's about embracing varied viewpoints and possibilities, rather than easily saying no.

It means I focus more on action than on making plans and continuously aim to learn more.

Living with an 𝗮𝘁𝗵𝗹𝗲𝘁𝗲'𝘀 𝗯𝗼𝗱𝘆 means I eat healthily and exercise daily. 

It means I prioritize sleeping early to ensure a good 8 hours of sleep. 

I take time to unwind and refresh my mind, with practices like stretching, meditation, fasting, and even trying out cold exposure.

Having an 𝗮𝗿𝘁𝗶𝘀𝘁'𝘀 𝘀𝗼𝘂𝗹 means I stay open to new experiences and continually find ways to express my creativity.

Trusting my intuition, even when I can't express it in words, is part of this journey.

It means I strive to be genuine and true to myself.

I wonder, what do these goals mean to you? 🧩

", 'Conversational and Clear Tone': "

When I think about having an 𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗲𝗽𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗲𝘂𝗿'𝘀 𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗱, I picture being in control and owning up to whatever comes my way.

content_of_the_post: Have you ever heard of the fresh start effect? It's when we're more likely to take action toward a goal after a special event or date has passed. Examples include New Year's Day, the first day of the month, or even a Monday. These can act as mental triggers for us to start something new. 👉 I learned about a strategy to create even more chances for fresh starts - dividing the day into smaller segments like 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴, 𝗮𝗳𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻𝗼𝗼𝗻, 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴. This way, if you miss an opportunity to do something, you can try again in a few hours. For example, if you have a tough morning, don't let it ruin the whole day - you can start fresh in the afternoon.🧩
rewrited_content:
{'Professional and Friendly Tone': '
Hello there! Are you familiar with something I like to call the "**𝗳𝗿𝗲𝘀𝗵 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁 𝗲𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗰𝘁**"? It's a fascinating thing, really. It's when we find ourselves more ready to step towards a goal after a special day or event has gone by. Think about how we often feel on New Year's Day, or the first day of a month, or even every Monday. It's as if these days push a button in our minds to encourage us to start something new.

Now, here's something interesting. I stumbled upon a strategy that creates more of these fresh start opportunities. How? By simply breaking our day down into smaller pieces, like "**𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴**", "**𝗮𝗳𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻𝗼𝗼𝗻**", and "**𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴**". 

If you miss an opportunity to do something, there's no need to worry. You'll have another chance in just a few hours. Let's say you have a rough morning. Well, that doesn't mean your entire day has to be spoiled. You can always choose to start fresh in the afternoon. 

🧩

content_of_the_post: Congrats TELUS!𝗥𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀' 𝗖𝗵𝗼𝗶𝗰𝗲 𝟮𝟬𝟮𝟯• Major Carrier: Among the [...] carriers that provide nationwide coverage, Telus comes out on top and earns a Readers' Choice Award• MVNO Carrier: Public Mobile blows away the competition on most of our satisfaction measures, earning the Telus subsidiary a Readers' Choice Award𝗕𝘂𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗖𝗵𝗼𝗶𝗰𝗲 𝟮𝟬𝟮𝟯• Business Carrier: Public Mobile is an MVNO owned by Telus and uses the Telus Mobility network. It offers low fees and high reliability, which propel it to the top of the list of carriers Canadians prefer for work
rewrited_content:
{'Professional and Friendly Tone': "
Big kudos to Telus! 
In the arena of the major carriers providing nationwide coverage, Telus stands out from the rest. 
**I've found** they've won a Readers' Choice Award, which is so exciting!
Another big winner in my eyes is Public Mobile.
They're a part of Telus, and they've outshone the rest on most satisfaction measures. 
**This has earned** them their own Readers' Choice Award!

Let's not forget about the Business Choice 2023.
When we think of a business carrier, Public Mobile springs to mind. 
**I know** that they are owned by Telus and use the Telus Mobility network.
They are appreciated for their low fees and high reliability.
**It's impressive** how they've made it to the top of the list of carriers that Canadians prefer for work. 🧩

", 'Conversational and Clear Tone': "
Hey there! Have you heard the great news about Telus? 🎉
**I've noticed** that among all the big carriers that cover our great nation, Telus has snagged a Readers' Choice Award! Pretty cool, right?

But that's not all. Public Mobile, which is part of Telus, has totally knocked it out of the park in most satisfaction areas! 🚀
**They've bagged** a Readers' Choice Award too! 🏆

Moving to the Business Choice 2023, **I've seen** that Public Mobile is a real hit for business carriers! 
They're under Telus and use the Telus Mobility network. 
And get this, they have low fees and excellent reliability. 🙌 
**They've earned** the top spot as the carrier Canadians love for work.📱Pretty awesome, huh? 🧩

", 'Clear and Concise Tone': "
**I've found** Telus has secured a significant win in 2023's Reader's Choice for major carriers. 
This award recognizes nationwide coverage providers, and Telus has risen above the competition.

In the MVNO Carrier category, Public Mobile, a Telus subsidiary, has surpassed the competition in most satisfaction measures. 
**They've merited** a Readers' Choice Award as well.

As for Business Choice 2023, **I've observed** Public Mobile taking the lead. 
As an MVNO owned by Telus using the Telus Mobility network, it's favored for its high reliability and low fees. 
**They've become** the top choice for Canadian businesses. 🧩
"}

content_of_the_post: Hi Linkedin,🎙️ We're back with the second and last part of the Careers in the Cloud podcast, in which we discuss recent layoffs at tech companies and my firsthand experiences with this challenging aspect of running a business.📢 I also share some communication strategies for staying connected with your team during challenging times and recommend resources to help managers succeed.📚  We then explore the nuances of managing different generations in the workplace, the keys to successful hiring, and reflect on the 'hire fast, fire faster' approach, considering its implications for your team.💡 Lastly, we discuss self-determination theory and how it might shape your management style.👉 Follow the link in the comments to watch the concluding part of the interview. As always, I hope you find it both enjoyable and insightful.🧩Click [+ Follow] for more
rewrited_content:
{'Professional and Friendly Tone': "
Hello everyone,

📣 I'm delighted to announce the return of the **Careers in the Cloud** podcast for its second and final part. During this episode, I talk about my own journey, dealing with recent layoffs at tech companies. It was indeed a tough part of running a business.

I've also found some effective ways to keep the team together during these hard times. You'll hear me share communication strategies that worked for me.

And what about the tools to help you excel as a manager? I have a few suggestions you'll find useful.

Do you know managing different age groups at work can be tricky? In the podcast, I dive into how this works, along with successful hiring tips.

content_of_the_post: Buongiorno Linkedin!🎙️ Come join me for Episode 24 of Careers in the Cloud, where I have the pleasure of discussing my professional journey from Italy to Canada and sharing insights from my work experiences.🌍 We discuss how the industry can influence career longevity and examine the distinctions between a lifestyle business and an impact business. Understanding these differences can be valuable when charting your professional course.💡 I also share the spark that inspired me to create free management content, which led me to start posting on LinkedIn every day for a whole year about 18 months ago.🤝 Finally we dive into the importance of networking and emphasize the need to find a networking approach that resonates with you.👉 Click the link in the comments to watch the interview. I hope you find it both enjoyable and informative.🧩Click [+ Follow] for more

**We'll also look at the difference between a lifestyle business and an impact business.**

content_of_the_post: Hey Linkedin, I recently had the pleasure of joining Maurizio Gioffrè on his excellent podcast, Careers in the Cloud, for a great conversation about Business and Life. We covered everything from the challenges of immigrating to Canada, to the thrill of leaving a small business behind for the big leagues of a large corporation and even delved into self-determination theory. You won't want to miss this chat, so stay tuned.🧩

Then, we touched on the exciting feeling of leaving a small company for a big one. 

We also talked about self-determination theory, a fascinating topic. 

**I believe you'll find our conversation interesting**. So, keep an eye out for it.

**🧩**

content_of_the_post: Enter the Rotary Cellphone by Justine Haupt.This retro-inspired device ditches touchscreens, menus, and apps. The “innovative” design fits in your pocket while still enabling users to make calls with ease.Unless the number you are calling has too many Zeroes and 9s 😜🧩
rewrited_content:
{'Professional and Friendly Tone': "
Hello there, I'd like to share my experience with a fascinating product - the **Rotary Cellphone** by Justine Haupt. Now, this isn't your typical modern phone. 

It's a step back in time, inspired by designs of the past, but with a fresh twist.

You won't find any touchscreens, menus, or apps here. 

What you'll get instead is a **charmingly simple** and **innovative** design that comfortably fits right in your pocket. 

With this device, you can easily place calls, a task that has become somewhat overshadowed in our current age of smart devices.

But, here's a friendly warning: if the number you're calling has too many zeroes and 9s, you might find yourself taking a little extra time dialing! 🧩

", 'Conversational and Clear Tone': '
Hey there! So, I got this super cool new phone, the **Rotary Cellphone** by Justine Haupt. It's like totally different from the phones we're used to, you know? 

It's kind of old-school, no touchscreens, no apps, no menus - like, really simple. 

But the cool part? The **"innovative" design** fits right in your pocket. 

You can make calls easily. 

Although, LOL, if the number has loads of zeroes and 9s, you might be there a while! 😜🧩

', 'Clear and Concise Tone': "
I'd like to introduce the **Rotary Cellphone** by Justine Haupt, a unique proposition in today's saturated smartphone market.

There's no touchscreen, no apps, no menus. It's a departure from the norm. 

This **innovative** design does more than stand out—it fits comfortably in your pocket. 

It simplifies the act of making calls, returning to the roots of telecommunication. 

However, dialing numbers with multiple zeroes and 9s may prove a bit more time-consuming. 🧩

"}

content_of_the_post: 𝗔𝗿𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗚𝗿𝗼𝘄𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝗿 𝗧𝗵𝗿𝗶𝘃𝗶𝗻𝗴?When it comes to growth and thriving, both involve progress and the development of new abilities. A growing plant is getting larger and developing new leaves and branches, whereas a thriving plant is not only growing but is also healthy and producing fruit. The same is true for people: a growing person is developing new skills and experiences, while a thriving person is not only developing new skills but is also happy and successful.
rewrited_content:
{'Professional and Friendly Tone': "
Hello friends,

**𝗜'd like to ask you a simple question, 𝗔𝗺 𝗜 𝗚𝗿𝗼𝘄𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝗿 𝗧𝗵𝗿𝗶𝘃𝗶𝗻𝗴?** 

Let's consider a plant. When a plant grows, it gets bigger, sprouts new leaves and branches.

That's exactly like us when we grow. We learn new things and gather new experiences. 

But, have you noticed a plant that not just grows, but thrives too? 

It's not only larger, but it's also bursting with health and bearing fruit. 

Likewise, when we thrive, it's not just about new skills or experiences.

**We're also content and find success in what we do.** 

And that's the essence of thriving - growing with joy and success!

🧩

", 'Conversational and Clear Tone': "
Hey there, 🙋‍♀️

**Ever wondered, am 𝗜 𝗴𝗿𝗼𝘄𝗶𝗻𝗴 or 𝗧𝗵𝗿𝗶𝘃𝗶𝗻𝗴? 🤔**

Think about a plant, right. 🌱 When it grows, it gets bigger and pops out new leaves and branches. 

That's pretty much us growing up too. We learn cool new stuff and live through some epic adventures! 🎒

But you've seen those super plants, haven't you? The ones that don't just grow, but totally thrive! 🌳 

They're not just bigger. They're super healthy and loaded with yummy fruit! 🍎 

That's like us, when we're not just growing, but thriving. 

**It's not just about learning new stuff or having experiences. It's about being happy and acing life! 😄🏆**

That's the real deal - thriving isn't just about growing, it's about growing with joy and success!

🧩

", 'Clear and Concise Tone': '
Greetings, 

**𝗜 pose a question to myself, 𝗔𝗺 𝗜 𝗚𝗿𝗼𝘄𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝗿 𝗧𝗵𝗿𝗶𝘃𝗶𝗻𝗴?** 

A growing plant increases in size, forms new leaves and branches - mirroring our personal and professional growth.

Yet, a thriving plant presents another layer, not merely growing, but radiating health and bearing fruit. 

**This is the parallel in human context - not just developing new skills or gaining experiences, but also achieving happiness and success.** 

Thus, the core idea - thriving extends beyond mere growth, it signifies growth combined with success and joy.

🧩
'}

content_of_the_post: Happy Spring Linkedin!Yesterday was the equinox, a special time of year when the day and night are of equal length. This is because the sun is directly above the Earth's equator, rather than north or south of it. Fun fact of the day: the word equinox comes from the Latin aequinoctium, which means equal night (aequus noctis). It occurs twice a year, around March 20th and September 23rd.🧩
rewrited_content:
{'Professional and Friendly Tone': "
**Hello, fellow LinkedIn members!** 
I hope you're all welcoming spring with open arms. 🧩

Just to share with you, **yesterday was the equinox.** 🧩

That's a very special time in our year. 🧩

It's the moment when our day and our night are exactly the same length. 🧩

How does this happen? 🧩

It's all because **the sun positions itself right over our Earth's equator**, not north or south of it. 🧩

Here's a cool piece of trivia for you: 🧩

The term 'equinox' finds its roots in Latin. 🧩

It's derived from 'aequinoctium', meaning 'equal night' ('aequus noctis'). 🧩

Amazingly, this event doesn't happen just once, but **twice a year** - typically around March 20th and September 23rd. 🧩

", 'Conversational and Clear Tone': "

It's when the daytime and the nighttime are the same length! 🌗 🧩

Wondering why? 🤔 🧩

It's because **the sun decides to chill right above the Earth's equator.** It's not hanging out to the north or south of it. 🌞 🧩

Here's a fun fact for you. 🤓 🧩

The word 'equinox'? It's got a Latin root. 🧩

It comes from 'aequinoctium', which means 'equal night' ('aequus noctis'). 🌃 🧩

And check this out, **we get to see this phenomenon twice a year** - usually around March 20th and September 23rd. 📅 🧩
clear and concise:
**Greetings, LinkedIn entrepreneurs!** 🧩

I trust you're welcoming the refreshing change of spring. 🧩

**Yesterday marked the equinox.** 🧩

A significant point in our year. 🧩

It signifies an equilibrium between day and night. 🧩

This balance is a result of **the sun situating itself directly above the Earth's equator.** 🧩

Here's an interesting detail: 🧩

The term 'equinox' stems from the Latin 'aequinoctium', translating to 'equal night' ('aequus noctis'). 🧩

Remarkably, this astronomical event recurs **twice annually**, around March 20th and September 23rd. 🧩

content_of_the_post: I learned that Payscale conducts a yearly study on the Gender Pay Gap, and below are the 2023 results 👇Like everyone else, I’ve heard about the gender pay gap many times in the media.I always assumed those figures referred to the “controlled” data (i.e. equal pay for equal work). It turns out they were the “uncontrolled” data (i.e. average pay of all men vs of all women). Glad to see we are further ahead than I thought. Now let’s close that last 1%.🧩
rewrited_content:
{'Professional and Friendly Tone': "
**Did you know Payscale runs an annual review looking at the Gender Pay Gap?** Well, it does and here are the findings from 2023.👇

Just like you, I've often seen reports on the gender pay gap in the news. 

Until now, **I had thought these numbers were 'controlled' figures.** This means men and women earning the same for doing the same job. 

But, surprise! The figures are actually 'uncontrolled'. 

In other words, they show the average earnings of all men and all women. 

Wow, I feel relieved! We're further along in this journey than I first believed. 

Now, our mission is to bridge the final 1% gap. Let's do this together. 🧩

Oh wow, we're doing way better than I thought! 😃

But there's still a tiny 1% left to fix. Let's crush this, guys! 🧩

**🧩**

content_of_the_post: OpenAI's 𝗚𝗣𝗧-𝟯, or Generative Pre-trained Transformer 3, has caught the world's attention for its ability to produce text closely resembling human speech. 👉 Their next iteration in the GPT series, 𝗚𝗣𝗧-𝟰 is launching next week!GPT-4 is estimated to have been trained with over 100 trillion parameters, which is significantly more than GPT-3's 175 billion parameters. 🤯 These numbers take time to comprehend. If we convert them into time units:• 175 billion seconds is about 5,500 years. That's about the number years elapsed from the construction of the Pyramids to today • 100 trillion seconds is 3,170,979 years or about 𝟲𝟯𝟬 𝘁𝗶𝗺𝗲𝘀 the years elapsed from the construction of the Pyramids 🧩
rewrited_content:
{'Professional and Friendly Tone': "
Hello! My journey with OpenAI's **𝗚𝗣𝗧-𝟯**, also known as Generative Pre-trained Transformer 3, has been quite interesting. 

It's so cool that this tool can generate text just like a human would. 

But, guess what? There's an upgrade coming soon! Next week, we'll be introduced to **𝗚𝗣𝗧-𝟰**. 

What's remarkable about GPT-4 is how big it is. It's believed to have over 100 trillion parameters. 

To give you a comparison, GPT-3 had 175 billion parameters. That's a big difference!

Imagine if each parameter was a second. 175 billion seconds would be like 5,500 years, around the time the Pyramids were built. 

But 100 trillion seconds? That's a staggering 3,170,979 years, which is **630 times** longer than the age of the Pyramids. 

Isn't that something to think about?

🧩

", 'Conversational and Clear Tone': "
Hey there! 😃 So, I've been hanging out with this AI buddy of mine called **𝗚𝗣𝗧-𝟯**. 

It's a creation by OpenAI that can write text just like us humans do! 📝

Now, they're about to launch an upgrade - **𝗚𝗣𝗧-𝟰**. Guess when? Next week! 🎉

This new version is super massive. It's supposed to have more than 100 trillion parameters. 😲

To put it in perspective, GPT-3 had 175 billion parameters. That's a huge jump!

Imagine this: if each parameter was a second, 175 billion seconds equals around 5,500 years. 🕰️ That's the time from when the Pyramids were built till now!

And 100 trillion seconds? It's a mind-blowing 3,170,979 years! That's like **630 times** the age of the Pyramids. 🤯 Crazy, right?

🧩

", 'Clear and Concise Tone': "
In my work with OpenAI's **𝗚𝗣𝗧-𝟯**, the AI's human-like text generation has been impressive. 

The upcoming version, **𝗚𝗣𝗧-𝟰**, is set for launch next week.

🧩

content_of_the_post: I was listening to a serial entrepreneur who said he stopped labelling things as Good or Bad because if he fails, it means he is about to learn something new.• Failure leads to Learning.• Learning leads to Success.• Success leads to Complacency.• Complacency leads to Failure.The cycle is inevitable. His message: Recognize where you are and try to overcome Complacency as quickly as possible.🧩#EntrepreneurshipClick [+ Follow] for more
rewrited_content:
{'Professional and Friendly Tone': "
Hi there! I want to share with you a piece of wisdom I got from a really smart business person. He told me he doesn't like to say things are good or bad anymore. Why, you ask? Well, when something doesn't work out, he knows he's going to learn something new from it.

🔸**Failure? It's really a chance to learn something!**

🔸**Learning? That's your ticket to success!**

🔸**Success? Be careful, it can make you complacent!**

🔸**Complacency? It could lead you back to failure.**

These steps, they kind of form a cycle. You might go through them again and again. His advice? Pay attention to where you're at, especially when you're feeling complacent. Try to get past that feeling fast, it's important!

**🧩**

Let's keep talking about being successful. Follow me to learn more!

", 'Conversational and Clear Tone': '
Hey, 🙋‍♂️ You won't believe what I heard from this awesome start-up guru! He's done away with the whole "good or bad" thing. If he stumbles and falls, he's like, "Cool, I'm about to learn something new." 😎

🔸**Falling flat on your face? 🤷 It's really learning in disguise! 😄**

🔸**Learning something new? 💡 Bam! You're on your way to success! 🎉**

🔸**Tasting success? 🏆 Oops, you might get too comfortable! 😴**

🔸**Getting too comfortable? 😬 Uh-oh, watch out for failure lurking around! 😵**

See, it's like a circle ⭕. It keeps going on. What's the guru's advice? Be aware of where you are in this cycle, especially when you're feeling too comfy. Shake that off ASAP! 💪

**🧩**

Want to hear more cool stuff like this? Follow me, dude! 😉

', 'Clear and Concise Tone': "
Greetings fellow entrepreneurs, I was in conversation with a seasoned entrepreneur recently, and his perspective was enlightening. He has done away with categorizing experiences as good or bad. His rationale? A failure merely signifies an upcoming learning opportunity.

🔸**A failure? It's the precursor to learning.**

🔸**The learning phase? That paves the way for success.**

🔸**Success? It can breed complacency.**

🔸**And complacency? It can herald failure.**

This cycle is inescapable. The insight he imparted? It's crucial to be aware of where you stand in this cycle and tackle complacency at the earliest.

**🧩**

Intrigued? Follow along for more insights into entrepreneurship.

"}

content_of_the_post: How to level up your hiring game 👇Increase your success rate by:• Brushing up on psychology• Taking every chance you get to bring on new talent• Finding ingenious ways to automate the background tasks• Being clear about what kind of team member you need for each roleThen, fine-tune your technique by regularly putting yourself in a decision-making situation and seeking constructive criticism from reliable sources. Revamp your process from time to time with fresh experiments, get the data to back you up, and repeat the cycle.🧩#HiringClick [+ Follow] for more
rewrited_content:
{'Professional and Friendly Tone': "
Hello there! It's me again. *I'd like to share some wisdom on how to make your hiring practices better.* First, let's start with understanding people. Why not pick up a book on psychology? 

I've found it really helps. Another thing I've found helpful is being open to new talent. 

*Whenever there's an opportunity to hire, take it.* You never know where your next superstar could be hiding. 

One thing I've done to make my life easier is to use clever systems to do the smaller tasks. 

I always make sure I know what I'm looking for in a team member for each job. *It really clarifies the hiring process.* 

And one of the most valuable things I've learned is to keep practicing and asking for feedback. 

I shake things up occasionally with new ideas, and keep track of the results. 

*The data doesn't lie, and it always guides my next steps.* 

Just keep at it, rinse, and repeat. 🧩

---

", 'Conversational and Clear Tone': '
Hey there! 😊 It's me again. I've learned some pretty cool things about hiring and I want to share them with you. 

First off, you know people are kind of complicated, right? 👤 *So, studying a bit of psychology has helped me understand them better.* 

I've also learned to say "yes" whenever I get the chance to add new talents to my team. 🚀 *You never know, the next great hire could be right around the corner!* 

Another thing that’s been a game-changer for me is automating the small stuff. 🤖 It frees up my time so I can focus on the important things. 

Being super clear about what I need from each role has been huge. 🎯 *It helps me find the perfect fit every time.*

And guys, let me tell you, putting myself in the decision-making seat often and seeking feedback has been crucial. 

I'm not afraid to try new things and see how they work. 🧪 And always, I mean always, I check the results. 

*Believe me, data doesn't lie.* 

Then, I do it all over again. So, keep at it, and see your hiring game level up! 🧩

---

Implement, learn, repeat - it's a simple cycle. 🧩

content_of_the_post: Are you ready to find the perfect fit for your team or organization? Then let's dive into how we assess candidates.At the core of our evaluation process are three key components: the Head, the Heart, and the Briefcase. 🧠 The 𝗛𝗲𝗮𝗱 represents a person's natural thought processes and decision-making style (aka their drivers). ❤️ The 𝗛𝗲𝗮𝗿𝘁 represents their values and alignment with the culture and vision of the team or organization. 💼 The 𝗕𝗿𝗶𝗲𝗳𝗰𝗮𝘀𝗲 represents their knowledge and experience, including the technical skills and relevant expertise needed for the role.The 𝗸𝗲𝘆 𝘁𝗼 𝘀𝘂𝗰𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀𝗳𝘂𝗹 𝗵𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 is finding a candidate who excels in all three areas. And to help us do that, we use a variety of tools and techniques to assess each aspect.🧠 𝗙𝗼𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗛𝗲𝗮𝗱 (𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗗𝗿𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀), we rely on a behavioural survey and a 1:1 phone screen to get a sense of how a candidate's brain naturally responds to the world.❤️ 𝗙𝗼𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗛𝗲𝗮𝗿𝘁 (𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗩𝗮𝗹𝘂𝗲𝘀), we use the phone screen and panel interview to gauge a candidate's alignment with our team's culture and vision.💼 𝗔𝗻𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗕𝗿𝗶𝗲𝗳𝗰𝗮𝘀𝗲 (𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗦𝗸𝗶𝗹𝗹𝘀), we turn to the panel interview and past samples of relevant work to assess a candidate's technical skills and expertise.It's important to note that none of these tools is perfect, and they should be considered holistically as part of the evaluation process. By looking at all the data points together, we can hopefully get a 𝗰𝗼𝗻𝘀𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗽𝗶𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲 of the candidate and determine if they are the right fit for the role.To learn more, get the 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝗲 Hiring Manager's Playbook here: 👉 http://bit.ly/3WI1xMc𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗮𝗽𝗽𝗹𝘆 𝗰𝗼𝗱𝗲  Linkedin100  𝗮𝘁 𝗰𝗵𝗲𝗰𝗸𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗮 𝟭𝟬𝟬% 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗻𝘁.🧩#HiringClick [+ Follow] for more
rewrited_content:
{'Professional and Friendly Tone': '
Hello there! I'd like to share my journey of finding the right team members. Here's my secret. **I look for three main things in a candidate**. I call them the "Head", "Heart", and "Briefcase".

In the "Head" section, I think about the candidate's natural way of thinking and making decisions.

The "Heart" part is about the values of the candidate. I ask, do they match with our team and organization's culture?

The "Briefcase" is all about their skills and experience. Can they do the job we're hiring for?

A good hire, I believe, is someone who ticks all these boxes. To make sure of that, I use a mix of tools and techniques.

For the "Head", I rely on a behavioural survey and a phone chat. This helps me understand how a candidate thinks.

For the "Heart", I use the same phone chat and an interview with a panel. This lets me see if the candidate fits with our culture and vision.

For the "Briefcase", the panel interview comes into play again, along with a look at past work. This gives me a good idea of their skills and expertise.

Remember, none of these methods are foolproof. That's why **I look at everything together**. That way, I get a full picture of the candidate. Then I can decide if they're right for the job.

Want to know more? Get the free Hiring Manager's Playbook at this link: http://bit.ly/3WI1xMc. Don't forget to use the code Linkedin100 at checkout for a full discount.

🧩

Second, the "Heart". Here I'm looking at their values. Do they fit with what our team is all about? ❤️

Finding someone who's got it all is what makes a great hire. And to figure that out, I use different ways.

content_of_the_post: I’ve started to follow more art and architecture accounts to include some “beauty” in my social media diet. This picture appeared in my feed recently and stopped me in my tracks. These are the four main structures in Piazza del Duomo (Cathedral Square) in Florence 🇮🇹1️⃣ The Cathedral of Santa Maria del Fiore2️⃣ The Baptistery of St. John3️⃣ The Brunelleschi's Dome4️⃣ The (Giotto’s) Bell TowerThe Cathedral was built over ~140 years (1296 to approx 1436) 🤯I thought I’d share a little bit of beauty with my LinkedIn friends too. Happy Sunday!🧩
rewrited_content:
{'Professional and Friendly Tone': '
Hello there! I've made a change in my online habits recently. I'm now checking out more profiles that talk about art and architecture. This change helps me find more "beauty" in my social media. One day, a photo popped up on my screen that truly caught my eye. 

This photo was of the four famous buildings in the Piazza del Duomo, which is a popular place in Florence, Italy. 🇮🇹 This place is home to four important buildings. 

The first one is **The Cathedral of Santa Maria del Fiore**. 

The second one is **The Baptistery of St. John**. 

The third one is **The Brunelleschi's Dome**.

The fourth one is **The (Giotto’s) Bell Tower**.

Did you know, it took a long time to build The Cathedral, about 140 years from 1296 to around 1436? 🤯

I just felt like showing this beautiful image with my LinkedIn friends. Wishing everyone a delightful Sunday! 🧩

This awesome picture just came up in my feed and it was so striking. It showed the four big stars of the Piazza del Duomo in Florence, Italy 🇮🇹. 

The first superstar is **The Cathedral of Santa Maria del Fiore**. 

Next up, we have **The Baptistery of St. John**.

The third one on the list is **The Brunelleschi's Dome**.

Last but not least, there's **The (Giotto’s) Bell Tower**.

Fun fact alert! 🚨 The Cathedral took around 140 years to build, starting in 1296 and finishing in about 1436. Mind-blowing, right? 🤯 

Thought I'd share this dose of beauty with all you peeps on LinkedIn. Here's to an amazing Sunday! 🧩

content_of_the_post: I like this quote.It captures the idea that true authenticity and fulfillment can be found when we approach our work with a balance of intensity and playfulness, much like a child.It reminds me of some of my most cherished professional memories. These were projects that were all-consuming but also incredibly fulfilling. Despite the long hours, they didn't feel like work. They felt like serious play with friends instead.These projects had a unique blend of hard work and laughter, constant collaboration and individual contribution, and a balance of carefully crafted master plans and unexpected emerging strategies. We focused on achieving serious business outcomes yet remained playful and lighthearted.Cheers to those projects (and friends), and to many more!🧩#QuotesClick [+ Follow] for more

content_of_the_post: One of the best things I did to improve my hiring process was to reduce the phone interview duration by half 💡In order to generate remarkable results in my hiring approach, I've made some minor but impactful adjustments. 1️⃣ Firstly, I've significantly shortened phone interviews from a half hour to just 15 minutes. This saves the interviewer (me) and the candidate time and ensures that the conversation stays focused on the most critical information.2️⃣ Furthermore, before beginning any interviews, I've taken the time to identify a specific behavioural profile I'm looking for in a candidate based on the job description (e.g. Predictive Index)This helps me understand what qualities will be most valuable for the role and allows me to choose in advance a set of behavioural questions that will be most informative. This saves time and also helps to reduce bias.3️⃣ Another change I made was creating email templates for the most common messages I sent during the hiring process (e.g. Beeftext)This saves me a lot of time, increases efficiency and definitely improves my own overall experience.4️⃣ Lastly, I've automated the scheduling process of coffee chats, phone interviews, panel interviews, and reference checking (e.g. Calendly).This streamlines the hiring process, makes it much easier for everyone involved and allows me to focus on the most crucial part: evaluating the candidates themselves.👉 I've saved time, reduced bias, and improved the candidate experience by making these adjustments to my hiring process. If you want to improve yours, consider adopting similar strategies. 🧩#ManagementClick [+ Follow] for more
rewrited_content:
{'Professional and Friendly Tone': "
Hello there! In my journey of refining my recruitment process, one of the smartest moves I made was to cut down on the phone interview time by half. 💡

Did this lead to great results? Yes, indeed! I made a few changes that had a big impact. Here's how: 

1️⃣ **My first step was to shorten phone interviews**. They now last just 15 minutes instead of 30. This gives both myself and the applicant extra time and makes sure we stick to the key details during our talk. 

2️⃣ **Next, I made sure to understand what kind of person I'm trying to find**. Before any interviews, I defined the particular behaviours I want to see, using the job's description to guide me (like a Predictive Index). This helps me know what traits are most important for the job and let me plan out the best questions to ask. It's a time-saver and helps me stay fair. 

3️⃣ **I also set up email templates** for the messages I find myself sending most often during the hiring process (like Beeftext). This has saved me heaps of time, made me more efficient, and improved my overall experience. 

4️⃣ **Finally, I made the scheduling process automatic** for things like coffee chats, phone interviews, panel discussions, and reference checks (using tools like Calendly). It makes hiring smoother and easier for everyone, and lets me concentrate on the most important thing: assessing the candidates. 

These changes have allowed me to save time, be more fair, and make the experience better for those applying. If you're looking to boost your hiring process, why not try these strategies? 🧩

", 'Conversational and Clear Tone': "
Hey, guys! 💁‍♂️ One cool thing I did that really helped my hiring game was to chop the phone interview time in half.💡

It totally transformed how I hire people. Here's what I did:

1️⃣ **First off, I cut the phone interviews short**. Instead of half an hour, they're now just 15 minutes. It's a win-win for me and the person I'm interviewing – we save time and keep our chats all about the key stuff. 

2️⃣ **Then, I worked out what kind of person I want for each job**. Before I even start interviews, I use the job description to decide what traits I'm looking for (kind of like a Predictive Index). This helps me focus on what matters most for the role and plan the best questions. It's quicker and fairer. 👍

3️⃣ **I also started using email templates** for the messages I send out most during hiring (thanks to Beeftext). It saves me so much time, makes me super efficient, and definitely makes my life easier.

4️⃣ **And lastly, I automated the scheduling process** for stuff like coffee catch-ups, phone interviews, group interviews, and checking references (using Calendly). It makes the whole hiring thing smoother and lets me focus on the really important bit – getting to know the candidates.

By making these changes, I've saved time, been more fair, and made the whole experience better for applicants. If you're looking to level up your hiring, why not give these tips a try? 🧩

2️⃣ **Next, I made sure to understand what kind of person I'm trying to find**. Before any interviews, I defined the particular behaviours I want to see, using the job's description to guide me (like a Predictive Index). This helps me know what traits are most important for the job and let me plan out the best questions to ask. It's a time-saver and helps me stay fair. 

3️⃣ **I also set up email templates** for the messages I find myself sending most often during the hiring process (like Beeftext). This has saved me heaps of time, made me more efficient, and improved my overall experience. 

4️⃣ **Finally, I made the scheduling process automatic** for things like coffee chats, phone interviews, panel discussions, and reference checks (using tools like Calendly). It makes hiring smoother and easier for everyone, and lets me concentrate on the most important thing: assessing the candidates. 

These changes have allowed me to save time, be more fair, and make the experience better for those applying. If you're looking to boost your hiring process, why not try these strategies? 🧩

Hey, guys! 💁‍♂️ One cool thing I did that really helped my hiring game was to chop the phone interview time in half.💡

It totally transformed how I hire people. Here's what I did:

1️⃣ **First off, I cut the phone interviews short**. Instead of half an hour, they're now just 15 minutes. It's a win-win for me and the person I'm interviewing – we save time and keep our chats all about the key stuff. 

2️⃣ **Then, I worked out what kind of person I want for each job**. Before I even start interviews, I use the job description to decide what traits I'm looking for (kind of like a Predictive Index). This helps me focus on what matters most for the role and plan the best questions. It's quicker and fairer. 👍

3️⃣ **I also started using email templates** for the messages I send out most during hiring (thanks to Beeftext). It saves me so much time, makes me super efficient, and definitely makes my life easier.

4️⃣ **And lastly, I automated the scheduling process** for stuff like coffee catch-ups, phone interviews, group interviews, and checking references (using Calendly). It makes the whole hiring thing smoother and lets me focus on the really important bit – getting to know the candidates.

By making these changes, I've saved time, been more fair, and made the whole experience better for applicants. If you're looking to level up your hiring, why not give these tips a try? 🧩

What qualities do they share?🧩#HiringClick [+ Follow] for more
rewrited_content:
{'Professional and Friendly Tone': "
Hello everyone! In my journey as a manager, I have had the chance to meet with many people for interviews. What I've noticed is that the finest candidates usually share these characteristics: 

**They are really good at what they do, but they don't brag about it.** 

**They come ready for the interview, but their responses are not robotic.**

**They know how to express themselves well, but they are never arrogant.**

content_of_the_post: OpenAI's 𝗚𝗣𝗧-𝟯, or Generative Pre-trained Transformer 3, has caught the world's attention for its ability to produce text closely resembling human speech. Their next iteration in the GPT series, 𝗚𝗣𝗧-𝟰 boasts an impressive increase in size compared to its current version. Specifically, GPT-4 is estimated to have been trained with over 100 trillion parameters, which is significantly more than GPT-3's 175 billion parameters. 🤯 These numbers take time to comprehend. If we convert them into time units:• 175 billion seconds is about 5,500 years. That's about the number years elapsed from the construction of the Pyramids to today • 100 trillion seconds is 3,170,979 years or about 𝟲𝟯𝟬 𝘁𝗶𝗺𝗲𝘀 the years elapsed from the construction of the Pyramids As a result, it will be even better at language production and translation tasks by processing and retaining more information and nuances in language. Unlike GPT-3, GPT-4 is not publicly available at the moment and is only accessible to a select group of academics and developers.🧩#AIClick [+ Follow] for more
rewrited_content:
{'Professional and Friendly Tone': "
Hello friends! 

Let's talk about something interesting. 

**OpenAI's 𝗚𝗣𝗧-𝟯** has really been making headlines. 

Why? 

Because it creates text that feels like it's written by a person. 

But now, there's something even more amazing on the horizon - **𝗚𝗣𝗧-𝟰**. 

You won't believe it but it's much bigger than GPT-3! 

Do you remember how big GPT-3 was? 

It was trained with 175 billion parameters. 

Now, guess how many parameters GPT-4 has. 

You won't believe it - it's 100 trillion! 😲 

Let's try to understand these big numbers. 

175 billion seconds is like 5,500 years. 

That's from the time the Pyramids were built till today. 

Now, 100 trillion seconds is 3,170,979 years! 

That's a very long time - about **630 times longer** than since the Pyramids were built! 

So what does this mean for GPT-4? 

It means it can do a better job at making text and understanding different languages. 

It can remember more details and pick up on the small things in language. 

But here's the thing, 

Right now, GPT-4 isn't available for everyone. 

It's only being used by a special group of people who study and make new technology. 

Well, that's all for now, folks! 

Remember to keep learning and asking questions. 🧩

content_of_the_post: Correction: In a previous version of this post, I incorrectly stated that the terms 'bull' and 'bear' in relation to the stock market originated from the movements of the animals themselves (i.e. bulls attack by swiping up, bears by swiping down). This is not the case. The terms originated from a proverb warning against selling the bear's skin before you have caught it. The term 'bear' was first used in the 18th century to refer to speculators selling stock they didn't own, expecting prices to drop. This practice was prevalent in the South Sea bubble scandal of 1720, which brought the term into widespread use. The term 'bull' was later coined to refer to those who bought securities or commodities expecting a price rise. The more you know.🧩#MarketsClick [+ Follow] for more
rewrited_content:
{'Professional and Friendly Tone': "
Hello there! I wanted to correct something I shared in a past post. I had mentioned that the terms 'bull' and 'bear', used in the context of the stock market, came from the behaviors of these animals. Well, turns out that's not quite right. 

In reality, these words come from an old saying. It was about not selling a bear's skin before actually catching the bear. 

In the 1700s, 'bear' became a nickname for people who would sell stocks they didn't own yet. They were hoping the prices would go down. 

This happened a lot during a time called the South Sea bubble scandal in 1720. After this event, more people started using the term 'bear'. 

Later on, the term 'bull' was used for people who bought stocks or other items because they thought the prices would go up. So now you know a little more about the stock market. 🧩

Don't forget to follow for more interesting facts! 

", 'Conversational and Clear Tone': '
Hey folks! 😊 Just wanted to make a quick fix about something I said earlier. 

You know how I told you that 'bull' and 'bear' for the stock market came from how these animals act? Well, I goofed up. 😅 

It actually came from an old saying. It's like "don't sell the bear's skin before you've caught the bear." 🐻 

Back in the 18th century, people started calling those who sold stocks they didn't even own yet 'bears'. They thought the prices would drop. 

This got really popular during a big event called the South Sea bubble scandal in 1720. After that, everyone started using 'bear'. 

Then, 'bull' was used for people who bought things because they believed prices would increase. 💰 Just a cool fact for you! 🧩

Keep following for more fun tidbits! 👍 

', 'Clear and Concise Tone': "
I need to correct an earlier post. 

I previously stated the terms 'bull' and 'bear' originated from animal behavior. This is incorrect. 

These terms come from an old proverb, warning against prematurely selling a bear's skin. 

The label 'bear' was first used in the 18th century. It referred to speculators who sold stocks they did not own, anticipating a price fall. 

This term gained traction during the South Sea bubble scandal of 1720. 

'Bull' was later used for those purchasing securities, expecting prices to rise. 

Knowledge improves decision-making in market trends. 🧩

Follow for more insights.

"}

Keep following for more fun tidbits! 👍
clear and concise:
I need to correct an earlier post. 

I previously stated the terms 'bull' and 'bear' originated from animal behavior. This is incorrect. 

These terms come from an old proverb, warning against prematurely selling a bear's skin. 

The label 'bear' was first used in the 18th century. It referred to speculators who sold stocks they did not own, anticipating a price fall. 

This term gained traction during the South Sea bubble scandal of 1720. 

'Bull' was later used for those purchasing securities, expecting prices to rise. 

Knowledge improves decision-making in market trends. 🧩

Follow for more insights.

rewrited_content:
{'Professional and Friendly Tone': '
Let's chat about something I've learned, called the "𝗕𝗮𝗯𝗯𝗹𝗲 𝗘𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗰𝘁". 

Ever noticed how people who talk a lot often become leaders? 

That's what this "Babble Effect" is all about. 

Funny thing is, this idea bothers some folks! 

Here's something that might surprise you: 

I don't think we should stop appreciating those who speak more. 

It's not a question of right or wrong, it's just that data shows us that talkative people often get rewarded. 

Now, good leaders can change how they run team chats, but it's not a lasting fix. 

What if, instead of hoping for a good leader, we encouraged quieter, skilled folks - I like to call them "𝗖𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗜𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗼𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘁𝘀" - to share their thoughts more often? 

You see, we can choose to speak up, that's within our power. 

But we can't always control if we'll have a good meeting leader. 

🧩

Now, let me share a story from my past. Once upon a time, I was a manager. When I talked about this, I mentioned the Self-Determination Theory. It's been a **"North Star" in how I work with others,** ever since I discovered it years ago.

content_of_the_post: 𝗔𝗿𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗹𝗼𝗼𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗮 𝘄𝗮𝘆 𝘁𝗼 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸 𝗲𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗹𝘆 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵 𝗼𝘁𝗵𝗲𝗿𝘀? If so, consider learning about the DISC personality framework.The DISC framework is often used in business and management settings to improve team members' communication, collaboration, and understanding. It was developed in the 1920s by Harvard psychologist William Moulton Marston. He proposed that there are four primary character types, each characterized by a set of distinct behavioural traits (although individuals will exhibit attributes from multiple traits): • Dominance (D)• Influence (I)• Steadiness (S)• Conscientiousness (C)The psychology field has evolved tremendously in the past 100 years, and today there are much more accurate behavioural tests (e.g. Big Five).That said, the DISC framework can still be a helpful introduction for those looking to learn more about 𝗱𝗶𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗿𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗺𝘂𝗻𝗶𝗰𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝘀𝘁𝘆𝗹𝗲𝘀 and how to interact effectively with others.When I first encountered DISC in 2016, I spent some time compiling all the information I could find on the different traits into 𝗮 𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗴𝗹𝗲 𝗱𝗼𝗰𝘂𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁.👉 I found it helpful at the time, so 𝗜'𝗺 𝗻𝗼𝘄 𝘀𝗵𝗮𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝘀 𝗰𝗵𝗲𝗮𝘁 𝘀𝗵𝗲𝗲𝘁 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵 𝘆𝗼𝘂. You can download it from here: http://bit.ly/3WYR8vSHave you ever used the DISC personality framework to understand your own behaviour or the behaviour of others? What was your experience with it?🧩⁠ ⁠ #ManagementClick [+ Follow] for more
rewrited_content:
{'Professional and Friendly Tone': "
- **I came across something special** back in 2016. I got to learn about a unique way to work effectively with others. It's called the DISC personality framework.🧩
  
- **This framework has roots in history**. A Harvard psychologist named William Moulton Marston developed it in the 1920s.🧩

- **The DISC framework introduces us to four main personality types**. Each type has specific behavioural traits. They are Dominance (D), Influence (I), Steadiness (S), and Conscientiousness (C).🧩

- **Though the psychology field has changed a lot since the 1920s**, this framework can still be a useful guide. It's especially good for understanding different communication styles.🧩

- **When I first learned about DISC**, I collected all the information I could. I then put it into one document. I'm sharing that document with you because I found it useful.🧩

- **You can download the document here**: http://bit.ly/3WYR8vS. I hope it helps you as much as it helped me.🧩

- **Have you tried using the DISC framework**? If yes, how was your experience?🧩

- **Follow my page for more interesting finds like this!** 🧩

content_of_the_post: Artificial Intelligence has a sense of humour 😮I jokingly asked ChatGPT to give me “the most ironic, satirical advice you can about using a structured interview process to select the best candidates”Here is the full reply 👇If you really want to find the best candidates for your open positions, forget about using a structured interview process. I mean, why waste time and effort asking consistent questions, evaluating skills and fit with company culture, and gathering references when you can just go with your gut?After all, your instincts are always right, right? You know what you like, and if you feel a spark of chemistry with a candidate, then they must be the one. And if they don't have the exact skills and experience that you're looking for, no problem! You can just train them on the job.So go ahead and ditch the structured interview process. Trust your gut, and hire the first candidate that you feel a connection with. I mean, what could go wrong?🧩#ArtificialIntelligenceClick [+ Follow] for more

{'Professional and Friendly Tone': '
**Hi there!** 🖐️ Let me share a story from my experiences. 
Once, someone asked me, ChatGPT, an Artificial Intelligence, for a funny piece of advice about hiring. 😄 

They said, **"ChatGPT, can you give me your most funny, tongue-in-cheek advice about picking the best team members using a formal interview process?"**

Here's what I shared: 👇

If you're looking for the right person for your team, why not forget about a formal interview process? 🤷 

Why bother with asking everyone the same questions, judging their skills, seeing if they fit your team's way of working, and checking references? Just follow your instinct! 

Your instinct is always perfect, right? 🤔 

You know what you like. And if you feel a good vibe with someone, they must be right for the job. And if they lack the exact skills and experience you need, that's okay! They can learn while they work. 

So why not let go of the formal interview process? Listen to your gut, and pick the first person who makes a good impression. After all, what could go wrong? 🤷 

What a joker I am, right? 🃏 

**#ArtificialIntelligence**
Remember, click [+ Follow] for more interesting advice like this! 

🧩

content_of_the_post: Improve your yearly performance review process with this easy-to-use assessment spreadsheet 👇Hey people leaders, it's time for performance reviews! Are you ready? ⁠⁠I've developed some tools over the years to make this task easier. ⁠⁠One of them is an assessment spreadsheet. Here's a quick rundown:⁠⁠First, I create a spreadsheet with dimensions to rate performance (e.g. decision-making, communication, relationships) in the first column. ⁠⁠Then, list team members' names in the other columns and assign values using a 5-point Likert scale. ⁠⁠This helps me more clearly articulate my thoughts on each individual's performance.⁠⁠👉 I find it helpful, so I'm sharing it with you. You can download it from here: http://bit.ly/3WC1x09 ⁠⁠Do you have any tips for assessing performance? ⁠⁠I'd love to hear how others tackle this critical task!!⁠🧩⁠⁠#ManagementTips⁠⁠Click [+ Follow] for more
rewrited_content:
{'Professional and Friendly Tone': "
Hello, everyone. It's time to talk about **yearly performance reviews**. Ready? 

I want to share with you a handy tool that I've been using. It's an **assessment spreadsheet**. 

Let me explain how it works. 

First, I make a **spreadsheet**. It has a few categories like decision-making, communication, and relationships. 

Next, I write the names of my team members in the other columns. 

I use a **5-point Likert scale** to grade each person's performance. 

This makes it much easier for me to talk about each person's work. 

I find this tool really helpful. That's why I want you to have it. Here's the link to download it: http://bit.ly/3WC1x09 

By the way, do you have any tips for performance reviews? 

I'm always keen to hear new ideas on this important task.

content_of_the_post: As we reflect on 2022, we need to acknowledge some historical milestones that we have reached. The population of the Earth has reached a staggering 𝟴 𝗯𝗶𝗹𝗹𝗶𝗼𝗻, and the global economy has surpassed $𝟭𝟬𝟬 𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗹𝗹𝗶𝗼𝗻.The International Monetary Fund estimates the current state of the world economy at $101.6 trillion, with the #UnitedStates accounting for 𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗾𝘂𝗮𝗿𝘁𝗲𝗿 𝗼𝗳 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗳𝗶𝗴𝘂𝗿𝗲. China and Japan follow in second and third place, with Canada rising to eighth place and Italy claiming the tenth spot.𝗛𝗼𝘄𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗿, 𝘁𝗵𝗲𝘀𝗲 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝘁𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗰𝘀 𝗱𝗼 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗽𝗮𝗶𝗻𝘁 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘄𝗵𝗼𝗹𝗲 𝗽𝗶𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲.They do not consider factors such as 𝗽𝗼𝗽𝘂𝗹𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝘀𝗶𝘇𝗲 (i.e. GDP per Capita), in which case #Europe claims the top spots, with Luxembourg, Ireland, and Norway leading the way. The United States falls to seventh place, Canada to eleventh, and Italy to thirty-first.Additionally, these figures do not consider the 𝗽𝘂𝗿𝗰𝗵𝗮𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗽𝗼𝘄𝗲𝗿 of a country's currency or what can you buy for $1? Using this measure, #China comes out on top, followed by the United States and #India. Italy and Canada trail behind in twelfth and fifteenth place, respectively.👉 It is clear that the World is a complex place, and to truly understand it, we must be willing to consider multiple perspectives.🧩#EconomyClick [+ Follow] for more
rewrited_content:
{'Professional and Friendly Tone': "
**🧩**

**Hi there!** I'm here to share a little bit about what happened in **2022**. 

**We had some big moments!** 

Do you know how many people live on Earth? We hit **8 billion**! That's a lot of friends! 

And guess what? Our whole world made over **$100 trillion**. Wow, that's a big number! 

The International Monetary Fund (IMF) says that our economy is worth **$101.6 trillion**. 

The **United States** made **one quarter of that**. 

**China** and **Japan** are next in line. 

**Canada** is eighth and **Italy** is tenth. 

But, these numbers don't tell us everything. 

They don't think about how many people live in a country. This is called GDP per Capita. 

When we think about this, **Europe** is the best. 

Countries like **Luxembourg**, **Ireland**, and **Norway** are doing great! 

The **United States** falls to seventh, **Canada** to eleventh, and **Italy** to thirty-first. 

Also, they don't tell us about the strength of a country's money. 

This is about what you can buy for $1. 

In this case, **China** is first, followed by the **United States** and **India**. 

**Italy** and **Canada** are a bit behind in twelfth and fifteenth place. 

So, the world is very interesting and a bit complicated! 

To really understand it, we have to think about different things. 

Thank you for joining me on this journey! 

Let's learn more together! 

**🧩**

", 'Conversational and Clear Tone': "

content_of_the_post: The 𝗙𝗿𝗲𝘀𝗵 𝗦𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁 𝗲𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗰𝘁 is a phenomenon that occurs when people are more likely to take action towards a goal after a special occasion or key date has passed. Examples of this include New Year's Day, the first day of the month, or even a Monday. These points in time can act as mental triggers for us to begin something new. 👉 Recently, I came across the idea that by dividing the day into multiple segments, 𝘀𝘂𝗰𝗵 𝗮𝘀 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴, 𝗮𝗳𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻𝗼𝗼𝗻, 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴, we can create more opportunities for fresh starts. This means that if you miss the chance to do something, the next trigger is just a few hours away. For instance, if you have a challenging morning, it doesn't have to ruin the entire day, and you can start anew in the afternoon. How have you leveraged the Fresh Start effect?🧩#LifeProTips Click [+ Follow] for more
rewrited_content:
{'Professional and Friendly Tone': "
Hi there, **I'd like to share something fascinating** with you. It's called the **𝗙𝗿𝗲𝘀𝗵 𝗦𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁 𝗲𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗰𝘁**. 

It's something that happens when we decide to take steps toward our goals. This usually happens after a special day or date.

Have you noticed this before? For example, on New Year's Day, the first day of a month, or maybe even a Monday?

These moments can make us feel like starting something new. 

Not too long ago, **I discovered something new about the Fresh Start effect**. 

We can break our day into parts like morning, afternoon, and evening. This gives us more chances for a fresh start.

It means that if we don't get to do something, the next chance is just a few hours away.

For example, if we have a tough morning, it doesn't have to ruin the whole day. We can try again in the afternoon.

**Have you ever tried the Fresh Start effect?** 🧩

Please follow for more!

content_of_the_post: Are any parents out there showing their kids a pre-recorded countdown video tonight so that the kids can go to bed early? And then, actually going to bed with them? 💡
rewrited_content:
{'Professional and Friendly Tone': "
**Hello, lovely parents!**

I was just thinking about how we can be smart about celebrating and getting a good night's rest. 

**Here's my little trick.**

Have you ever thought about showing your children a pre-recorded countdown video in the evening? 

It could be a fun way to let them experience the countdown excitement. 

**And then, guess what?**

After the 'midnight' celebration, tuck them into bed a little early. 

**Now, for the best part.**

Instead of staying up late, why not join them in peaceful slumber? 

Remember, **good rest is important for us too!** 

So, how about giving it a try tonight? 

🧩

", 'Conversational and Clear Tone': "
**Hey there, cool parents! 😎**

I've got this cool idea I've been doing. 

Ever thought of showing your kiddos a recorded countdown video before their bedtime? 🎥🕛 

It's like having a mini-party for them! 🎉

**And then, here's the trick!**

After they celebrate 'midnight', you tuck them in early. 🛌💤

**But wait, there's more!**

Instead of you staying up late, how about snoozing along with them? 😴

Trust me, it works wonders! 🌙✨

Ready to try it tonight? 🌟

🧩

", 'Clear and Concise Tone': "

After the early 'midnight' festivity, lead them towards an early bedtime. 

**Finally, a tactic for your wellbeing.**

Does this resonate with your innovative mindset? 

🧩
"}

content_of_the_post: Did you know that today is the (winter) solstice? This means that starting tomorrow, the days will be getting longer for those of us in the northern hemisphere! 👌Fun fact: the word solstice comes from the Latin words sol (sun) and sistere (to stand still). This is because at the solstices, the Sun's movement seems to stand still before changing direction. 🧩
rewrited_content:
{'Professional and Friendly Tone': "
Hi there! **I've got some exciting news to share with you today.** Did you know it's the winter solstice? This means that from tomorrow onward, our days will start to get longer if we're living in the northern hemisphere. Isn't that a wonderful thought?

**Here's a little trivia for you**: the term 'solstice' comes from two Latin words - 'sol', which means sun, and 'sistere', meaning 'to stand still'. I find it fascinating because during the solstices, the Sun's movement appears to pause before it changes direction.

Pretty cool, isn't it?

🧩

content_of_the_post: 𝗔𝗿𝗲 𝘄𝗲 𝗚𝗿𝗼𝘄𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝗿 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝘄𝗲 𝗧𝗵𝗿𝗶𝘃𝗶𝗻𝗴?The other day I was talking with a dear friend about the difference between the two terms. I couldn’t articulate it very well, so I looked it up. Growing and thriving are similar in that they both refer to the development of new abilities, the expansion of existing ones or some form of progress. However:A growing plant is getting bigger and developing new leaves and branches. Likewise, a 𝗴𝗿𝗼𝘄𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗽𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗼𝗻 is developing new skills and experiences that help them become more capable and knowledgeable.Instead, a thriving plant is not just getting bigger but is also healthy and producing flowers or fruit. Likewise, a 𝗽𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗼𝗻 𝘁𝗵𝗿𝗶𝘃𝗶𝗻𝗴 is not just developing new skills but is also happy and successful.👉 In summary, growth refers to progress, expansion and development of new skills. Thriving, on the other hand, implies that something is not just growing but is also healthy and prosperous. As we consider the future of our career, company, or family, it is helpful to ask ourselves whether we are simply growing or if we are truly thriving. 🧩
rewrited_content:
{'Professional and Friendly Tone': "
Did you know there's a difference between **growing** and **thriving**? I had a heart-to-heart with a good friend about this, but it was tough to explain. So, I decided to figure it out myself. 

Turns out, growing and thriving share some things. They both mean getting better at something, learning more, or moving forward. But here's the twist:

When we say a plant is **growing**, it means it's getting bigger, sprouting new leaves, and branches. And guess what? When I say **I'm growing**, I mean I'm learning new things and getting better at stuff I already know. 

Now, a plant that's **thriving** is not just getting bigger. It's also healthy and may even have flowers or fruits. So, when **I'm thriving**, I'm not just learning new things. I'm also feeling great and doing well in life. 

So here's the big idea: Growth means getting better, learning more, and becoming stronger. But thriving? It means you're not just getting better. You're also doing really well. So next time you think about your job, your business, or your family, ask yourself: Am I just growing, or am I really thriving? 🧩

", 'Conversational and Clear Tone': "
Hey there! Have you ever wondered what's the difference between **growing** and **thriving**? 🤔 I had a chat with a friend about this and it got me thinking. 

Growing and thriving might seem similar, right? Both mean getting better at stuff, learning, or moving up in some way. But here's the deal: 

Imagine a plant. When it's **growing**, it's just getting bigger, popping out new leaves and branches. Just like that, when **I say I'm growing**, I mean I'm picking up new skills and getting better at things I already know. 🌿

But, a plant that's **thriving**? It's not just bigger. It's also healthy and might even have flowers or fruits. That's pretty cool, huh? So when **I say I'm thriving**, I don't just mean I'm learning more. I also mean I'm feeling awesome and things are going pretty great for me. 🌼🌻

In a nutshell, growth is about getting better, learning more, and going forward. Thriving, on the other hand, means not just growing, but also being in a pretty good place. So, the next time you're thinking about your life, school, or family, ask yourself: Are you just growing, or are you truly thriving? 🧩

", 'Clear and Concise Tone': "
Have you pondered the difference between **growing** and **thriving**? I found myself discussing this with a friend, but it wasn't easy to define. So, I took it upon myself to clarify. 

Growing and thriving might seem synonymous; both involve acquiring new abilities, enhancing existing ones, or making progress. Yet, here's the distinction:

A **growing** plant increases in size, developing new leaves and branches. Similarly, when **I say I'm growing**, it indicates I'm acquiring new skills, gaining experiences that enhance my knowledge and capability.

In contrast, a **thriving** plant is not only bigger but also healthy, possibly bearing flowers or fruit. Consequently, when **I indicate that I'm thriving**, it implies that I'm not just developing new skills
"}

rewrited_content:
{'Professional and Friendly Tone': "
Hello friends,

**I** recently came across a technological advancement that **I** couldn't wait to share with you. It's something everyone has been talking about - artificial intelligence or AI. We often hear that it is set to change everything, yet many of us feel left behind because we don't see how we can use it every day. Well, **last week that changed for me**. 

Open AI, a pioneering organization, launched a tool called ChatGPT. **I** had the opportunity to test it out, and **I** must say, it's truly a game-changer. This tool can understand and respond to what you say, much like a real person would. In fact, over a million people are already using it!

From my experience with it, **I** found that ChatGPT is not just great at helping with writing tasks, but also excels in generating fresh ideas, providing strategic insights, and teaching new concepts. While the answers it provides may not always be perfect, **I** would rate them at least **5 out of 10**, even in these early stages. That's impressive, especially since it's a free tool!

Here are some of the things **I** tried with ChatGPT:

• Demonstrating how to calculate when and how much inventory to restock
• Crafting a professional email to maintain contact after a meeting
• Discussing whether life is more like Poker or Chess
• Explaining blockchain technology to a young child
• Listing the top 3 skills to develop before AI dominates our lives

**I** invite you to try ChatGPT for yourself at 𝗖𝗵𝗮𝘁[.]𝗢𝗽𝗲𝗻𝗔𝗜[.]𝗰𝗼𝗺. **I** would be interested to hear your thoughts - do you think it's a game-changing tool?

🧩

content_of_the_post: Here are 𝟭𝟬 𝘁𝗮𝗸𝗲𝗮𝘄𝗮𝘆𝘀 from Annie Duke’s excellent book Thinking in Bets: Making Smarter Decisions When You Don't Have All the Facts.1. Life is more like 𝗣𝗼𝗸𝗲𝗿 than Chess (chess is computation, while real-life also consists of luck and occasional deception)2. All decisions are bets, and we should think in 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗯𝗶𝗹𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗰 terms (i.e. likelihood), not absolutist terms (i.e. true/false)3. 𝗢𝘂𝘁𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗲 𝗕𝗶𝗮𝘀 (aka Resulting) is our tendency to believe that a good outcome signifies a good decision. And a bad result is a sign of a wrong decision4. Instead, good decisions can generate adverse outcomes at times, and 𝘃𝗶𝗰𝗲-𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗮5. The goal is to improve the quality of decision-making because, over time, it will generate a higher 𝗹𝗶𝗸𝗲𝗹𝗶𝗵𝗼𝗼𝗱 of success6. Create a system to encourage and gather 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝘀𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 viewpoints instead of silencing them (e.g. red team)7. The way we feel about outcomes is 𝗽𝗮𝘁𝗵 𝗱𝗲𝗽𝗲𝗻𝗱𝗲𝗻𝘁 (e.g. win $1000 at the casino and then lose them vs lose $1000 and then win them back)8. Use the 𝟭𝟬-𝟭𝟬-𝟭𝟬 𝗿𝘂𝗹𝗲 to get perspective on decisions: ask how you'll feel in 10 minutes, 10 months, and 10 years9. Use 𝗕𝗮𝗰𝗸𝗰𝗮𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 (i.e. working backwards from a positive future) instead of Forecasting (i.e. making predictions based on past data)10. Host a 𝗣𝗿𝗲𝗺𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗲𝗺 i.e. Imagine we failed to achieve our goals. What went wrong, and how do we mitigate it?10/10 would recommend it.🧩
rewrited_content:
{'Professional and Friendly Tone': "
I want to share some valuable learnings from Annie Duke’s splendid book, Thinking in Bets: Making Smarter Decisions When You Don't Have All the Facts.

Here's an interesting thought.
**Life is more like Poker than Chess.**
While chess is about calculation, real-life brings in luck and occasional deception too.

Next, a neat observation. 
**All decisions are bets**.
We should think more in terms of 'chances' rather than 'right or wrong'.

Another takeaway is about **Outcome Bias**. 
Sometimes we think that a good outcome means a good decision and a bad outcome points to a wrong decision.

But truth is, good decisions can sometimes lead to bad outcomes. And it can happen the other way around too.

The aim should always be to improve our decision-making skills. 
Why? 
Because, over time, this will increase the **chances of success**.

Here's a useful tip.
Create a system that welcomes different viewpoints instead of shutting them down.

Also, remember our feelings about outcomes depend on the **path we've taken**. For example, how would you feel if you win $1000 at a casino and then lose them, compared to if you lose $1000 and then win them back?

Ever heard of the **10-10-10 rule**? 
Ask yourself how you'd feel about a decision in 10 minutes, 10 months, and 10 years.

Try **Backcasting**. 
This is all about working backwards from a positive future instead of making predictions based on past data.

Lastly, host a **Premortem**. 
Imagine we didn't achieve our goals. What went wrong? How can we prevent it?

I highly recommend this book! 🧩

", 'Conversational and Clear Tone': ''}
professional_and_friendle:
I want to share some valuable learnings from Annie Duke’s splendid book, Thinking in Bets: Making Smarter Decisions When You Don't Have All the Facts.

Here's an interesting thought.
**Life is more like Poker than Chess.**
While chess is about calculation, real-life brings in luck and occasional deception too.

Next, a neat observation. 
**All decisions are bets**.
We should think more in terms of 'chances' rather than 'right or wrong'.

Another takeaway is about **Outcome Bias**. 
Sometimes we think that a good outcome means a good decision and a bad outcome points to a wrong decision.

But truth is, good decisions can sometimes lead to bad outcomes. And it can happen the other way around too.

The aim should always be to improve our decision-making skills. 
Why? 
Because, over time, this will increase the **chances of success**.

Here's a useful tip.
Create a system that welcomes different viewpoints instead of shutting them down.

Also, remember our feelings about outcomes depend on the **path we've taken**. For example, how would you feel if you win $1000 at a casino and then lose them, compared to if you lose $1000 and then win them back?

Ever heard of the **10-10-10 rule**? 
Ask yourself how you'd feel about a decision in 10 minutes, 10 months, and 10 years.

Try **Backcasting**. 
This is all about working backwards from a positive future instead of making predictions based on past data.

Lastly, host a **Premortem**. 
Imagine we didn't achieve our goals. What went wrong? How can we prevent it?

I highly recommend this book! 🧩

content_of_the_post: Happy Thanksgiving long weekend to my friends south of the border. Enjoy your holiday!🧩

Last week the world population reached 8 Billion people! Growing up, I heard about the dangers of endless overpopulation.Instead, we'll peak at about 10.4 billion in 2086 before falling again.Here's how quickly the population grew:• It was in 1805 that the world reached its first billion; it then took another 120 years to reach two billion. • By the third billion, this period had reduced to 35 years, reduced further to 14 years to reach four billion. • The fastest growth occurred from 1974 to 2011, taking only 12 to 13 years to increase by one billion for the 5th, 6th, and 7th.• The world has now surpassed the peak growth rate, and the period between each billion will continue to rise. • It's estimated to take approximately 14 years to reach nine billion in 2037 and a further 21 years to reach 10 billion in 2058. 🧩

𝗗𝗼𝗻'𝘁 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝗼𝘁 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗺𝗲𝘀𝘀𝗲𝗻𝗴𝗲𝗿!I used to think this was a warning about fairness, about not making the messenger pay for someone else's misconduct.I learned today it's about self-preservation instead 🤯While the phrase originates in the fog of history, one of its earlier documented use is by Plutarch when he writes about Tigranes, King of Armenia.When a messenger gave notice of a political enemy coming to see him, Tigranes had the messenger's head cut off. After that incident, no one dared bring any further negative information. Tigranes, while at war, had no enemy intelligence, ultimately resulting in several military defeats.👉 My takeaway, in a business setting: listen to dissenting views instead of silencing or ignoring them.🧩
I'm reading a book about decision-making in Business and Life. The author is using Chess and Poker as two possible models.I'm curious, what does LinkedIn think?🧩
Who neither knows victory nor defeat 🧩
As a European, I can confirm it checks out 💯🧩
Requirements elicitation for software development is indeed both an Art and a Science 😜
Would you attend? Why or why not? 👇

As someone who likes Lean, systems, playbooks - and efficiency - this stopped me in my tracks.Did I completely miss the point? 𝘐𝘧 𝘸𝘦 𝘸𝘢𝘯𝘵 𝘴𝘰𝘮𝘦𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘵𝘰 𝘦𝘯𝘥𝘶𝘳𝘦, 𝘸𝘦 𝘴𝘵𝘳𝘪𝘷𝘦 𝘧𝘰𝘳 𝘣𝘦𝘢𝘶𝘵𝘺, 𝘯𝘰𝘵 𝘧𝘰𝘳 𝘦𝘧𝘧𝘪𝘤𝘪𝘦𝘯𝘤𝘺.I suspect this applies beyond architecture and urban planning. It's an invitation to reflect on how I can introduce Beauty to my work. And in the other aspects of Life.🧩
So simple, yet so effective! Anyone could do the same to locate their organization's best teams/leaders.In what other scenario would it be clever to use this approach?🧩

Have you heard we live in a VUCA world?It means that Volatility, Uncertainty, Complexity and Ambiguity make it challenging to understand the present and predict the future.Change Management, therefore, is the arena where companies, departments and individuals battle the VUCA world. The Knoster model (below) is a framework for Change Management that shows how each “ingredient” contributes to the “recipe.”🧩
I think the same is true for any team 👇

𝘍𝘪𝘹 𝘸𝘩𝘢𝘵 𝘣𝘰𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘳𝘴 𝘺𝘰𝘶, 𝘯𝘰 𝘮𝘢𝘵𝘵𝘦𝘳 𝘩𝘰𝘸 𝘴𝘮𝘢𝘭𝘭.I like this quote. It has stuck with me since when I found it years ago.What it made me realize is that:𝗜𝗳 𝘀𝗼𝗺𝗲𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗯𝗼𝘁𝗵𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝘂𝘀, 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝘁𝗿𝗶𝘃𝗶𝗮𝗹.Whatever it is, no matter how small, I try not to let it linger. Otherwise, it keeps taking my mental bandwidth. It occupies more of my cognitive real estate.And soon enough, there is less of me and more of these nuisances.Instead, when I fix the small things, I have more power and skills to improve the bigger things.What bothers you today?🧩

I attended an insightful session about Design Thinking & Innovation led by Madeleine Baker today. We also went through a few exercises I can reuse with the product I support - such as User group definition, Empathy map, How Might We reframing.Here are the main takeaways for me:• Design Thinking is about disciplined engagement in the practice of Innovation• There are *many* ways to innovate (7 Modes, 10 Types)• Reframing the problem creates space for new ideas and solutionsVery timely and relevant in my new role.10/10 would recommend.🧩

Is this your first time hiring someone, and you don’t know where to start? Are you worried about hiring the wrong person?👇Like you, I received zero training on conducting my first hiring round years ago. 𝗧𝗵𝗶𝘀 𝗽𝗹𝗮𝘆𝗯𝗼𝗼𝗸 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗱𝗼𝗰𝘂𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗜 𝘄𝗶𝘀𝗵 𝗜 𝗵𝗮𝗱. It's a curated collection of strategies I've learned from people smarter than me and tools I've created to organize my hiring efforts. Download it free from the Featured section or in the comments below. 🧩Click [+ Follow] for more
You either move closer to or further from the goal🧩

I like this framework from McKinsey & Company but they got one thing wrong 👇They identify 3 keys to faster, better decisions (below). But I don’t know why they consider hiring as low-risk and frequent for most managers.It’s quite the opposite. From a manager's perspective, hiring is high-impact and very infrequent (i.e. difficult to get good at), which is why it's risky.Even from a company's perspective, hiring might be frequent (i.e. it's happening all the time, somewhere), but it is not low-risk.Do you consider hiring a High or Low risk activity?🧩

Eric Brummel captured Earth spinning through space 👇Incredible how this short time-lapse shows so clearly something we are aware of but usually cannot perceive.Astrophotographers achieve this effect with a motorized Equatorial Mount, compensating for Earth's rotation, so the camera stays fixed on the celestial object. 🧩
A little window of Consciousness 🧩

I recently learned about @eLegend, a “Retrofuturistic Full Electric Supercar” reinterpreting the rally legend Audi Sport Quattro from the 1980s.I can see how bringing back old models with electric propulsion could become a real trend. What retrofuturistic car you'd love to see?I'll go first: Lancia Delta Integrale🧩
Proof that pragmatic innovation is the key to success🧩

Today I completed the first week entirely dedicated to my new role in product management 👇It's like drinking from a firehose, of course. But I've learned more about the company's inner workings and met more new people in the past five days than in the previous year.For many new employees, it would be an excellent training and networking opportunity to spend a couple of weeks shadowing a product manager when they first join.I'm going to put a note in the suggestion box near the water cooler.🧩
For anyone looking for a new snowboard design 👇🧩

As someone that enjoys systems, playbooks and streamlining processes, this hit close to home 😁 I’ve been there many times. Still worth it. I’m currently looking at ways to automate inventory reporting. We’ll see how it goes. 🧩
Unpopular opinion: this Tweet is about leadership 👇🧩
