I’m wrapping up the week with a few wins:• A cliffhanger project is wrapping up juuuust in time • I got unsolicited positive feedback about a team member• A connection made a few weeks ago is leading to a possible career discussion for another team member • My backfill is a great leader who will take on my former team without skipping a beatTonight I am celebrating 🍷 Have a great weekend, everyone! 🧩
What a great quote 👇
To my friends in SaaS software development:

Apparently there is a good amount of quality research suggesting that binaural beats of 40 Hz can shift the brain into a very focused state. It increases concentration and cognition, mainly if used for 5 minutes before starting mentally demanding work. I’ll try it out next time I’m doing some Deep Work (e.g. year-end comments and evaluations). 🧩

Today I started a new role as Sr Technical Product Manager for TELUS Business Wi-Fi. After several years in Systems Strategy and in Project Delivery, getting closer to the Customer again is exciting.I look forward to working with the Sales, Marketing, Fulfillment, Care and Systems teams in this new mandate.  I'm grateful for the outstanding people I got to work with over the years, the leaders I've been coached by and the friendships I've made. Your kind comments over the past few days were heartwarming.I am eager to learn about this side of the business and looking forward to whatever this new adventure may bring. Let's go.🧩
Happy Halloween 🎃 👻 💀
Speak up. We, collectively, need your ideas and contribution.🧩
Friendly reminder that the year is 83% done, and there are 9 weeks left until 2023. #FinishStrong🧩

Yesterday I was looking at the nominations for a prestigious company award. There must have been over 300 pictures, with people from all business functions.I was happy to find many deserving team members I’ve met and worked with over the years.And what a beautifully multicultural and multifaceted team! Proud. 🧩

This morning I was listening to an interview with James Clear about how the environment around us drives our habits unconsciously. The point is to be deliberate about how we organize our surroundings, to facilitate good habits and dissuade bad ones. This applies to both physical and digital environments. So I’m testing a couple of ideas mentioned in the interview: 1. Rearrange the Home Screen to include only essential apps2. Use black and white screen settings to reduce the allure of the colourful “eye candy” appsThis is going to be interesting. 🧩

I found this graph helps to put in context the current economic outlook.During an average Bear market (i.e. when securities fall for a sustained amount of time), the S&P “𝘩𝘢𝘴 𝘴𝘭𝘪𝘥 𝘢𝘣𝘰𝘶𝘵 38% 𝘰𝘷𝘦𝘳 15 𝘵𝘰 16 𝘮𝘰𝘯𝘵𝘩𝘴 𝘣𝘦𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘦 𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘤𝘩𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘢 𝘣𝘰𝘵𝘵𝘰𝘮.”🧩

One year ago today, I challenged myself to post on LinkedIn daily for a year. Here are 5 of the lessons I've learned 👇1. 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗳𝗶𝗿𝘀𝘁 𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗽 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗵𝗮𝗿𝗱𝗲𝘀𝘁 𝗼𝗻𝗲. One of the early challenges was overcoming the feeling that the knowledge or insights I have to share are obvious. It turns out they aren't.2. 𝗕𝗲 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗳𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵 𝗮𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗴𝘂𝗶𝘁𝘆. I've no idea what will resonate. Some of what I thought was my best content would be ignored. While something I wrote almost in passing would become a popular piece. 3. 𝗖𝘂𝘀𝘁𝗼𝗺𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝗱𝗲𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗩𝗮𝗹𝘂𝗲. I used to think that Quality matters more than Quantity. I now believe you need Quantity (i.e. volume, data points) to understand what Quality looks like to my customers. That's because my own definition of Value might be way off. 4. 𝗣𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗼𝗻𝗮𝗹 𝗦𝘁𝗼𝗿𝘆𝘁𝗲𝗹𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗲𝘀𝘁 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝗯𝗲𝘁𝘄𝗲𝗲𝗻 𝗽𝗲𝗼𝗽𝗹𝗲. Writing about how the topic at hand relates to me personally, even if only in a small way, will make it resonate more. For example, when I write about my journey or the World seen through my daughter's eyes. 5. 𝗙𝗶𝗻𝗱 𝗮 𝗻𝗲𝘁𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮𝗽𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗮𝗰𝗵 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝘀 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘆𝗼𝘂. I (wrongly) used to think that networking was about self-involved superficial conversations. However, through the daily posting, I discovered a new angle to networking that made it click for me. 🧩

Today we are launching a new set of features and hundreds of UI/UX improvements to several thousands of our users.That’s the final stretch of a 15 months project involving 30+ groups, 100s of business primes and countless planning, development and testing hours. And it’s the critical step because 𝗨𝘀𝗲𝗿 𝗔𝗱𝗼𝗽𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗶𝘀 𝘄𝗵𝗲𝗿𝗲 𝗕𝘂𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗩𝗮𝗹𝘂𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗹𝗶𝘇𝗲𝗱. It’s going to be a busy week 💪🧩
If a Spotify playlist was a Digital Product Manager... 😁A surprisingly good listen!🧩

This is how I realized I'm not cut for a role in corporate marketing:During my second year at a leading Canadian telecommunication company that shall remain nameless, I was sitting on a marketing call for an upcoming campaign.We spent 20 minutes deciding whether the most suitable critter was a bunny or a piglet.I decided right there it was not for me.What was your I need to change something moment?🧩

Here's a talent acquisition pool that's way underused:𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗿𝘂𝗻𝗻𝗲𝗿-𝘂𝗽 𝗰𝗮𝗻𝗱𝗶𝗱𝗮𝘁𝗲𝘀 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗱𝗶𝗱𝗻'𝘁 𝗵𝗶𝗿𝗲 𝗹𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝘁𝗶𝗺𝗲.I don't know why we tend to start from scratch every time we have a new opening.Instead, look at the shortlist of previous candidates. It's a potential gold mine. Do you have one talent acquisition trick you can share?🧩

One of the mistakes I made as a new manager was looking for the best people to join my team. Instead, I should have focused more time and energy on accountability, coaching and career planning for the people already there with me.It seems obvious in retrospect, but sometimes the easier lessons are learned the hard way.What mistakes have you made early on as a manager?🧩

I was listening to an interview about hiring talent, and the CEO of this company said they approach the application generation system for Candidates like the lead generation system for Sales 💡To me, that means things like:- The job title becomes your headline - Speed and responsiveness are critical- Nurture the candidates that didn’t make it yetWhat else?🧩
I think this is an excellent definition of two critical business skillsets:Management deals with Complexity. Leadership deals with Change.🧩

This is funny because it’s true. Product/market fit is the degree to which a product satisfies market demand.  𝘐𝘵’𝘴 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘧𝘪𝘳𝘴𝘵 𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘱 𝘵𝘰 𝘣𝘶𝘪𝘭𝘥𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘢 𝘴𝘶𝘤𝘤𝘦𝘴𝘴𝘧𝘶𝘭 𝘷𝘦𝘯𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦 𝘸𝘩𝘦𝘳𝘦 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘤𝘰𝘮𝘱𝘢𝘯𝘺 𝘮𝘦𝘦𝘵𝘴 𝘦𝘢𝘳𝘭𝘺 𝘢𝘥𝘰𝘱𝘵𝘦𝘳𝘴, 𝘨𝘢𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘳𝘴 𝘧𝘦𝘦𝘥𝘣𝘢𝘤𝘬 𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘨𝘢𝘶𝘨𝘦𝘴 𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘦𝘳𝘦𝘴𝘵 𝘪𝘯 𝘪𝘵𝘴 𝘥𝘦𝘷𝘦𝘭𝘰𝘱𝘮𝘦𝘯𝘵. 🧩

Here we go again. Over the weekend, our IT partners will promote several SaaS projects and features to the Production Environment. This is a big weekend, with several significant projects delivering excellent capabilities for our Customers and internal teams. Many months of work from my team and hundreds of other team members will culminate in this milestone. Good luck to all involved!🧩

On Tuesday this week, two different people reached out to me with positive unsolicited feedback (undoubtedly the best kind) about two of my team members. I know their value, and I’m happy to see others recognizing it. It made my day. It made their day. It made my boss’ day. But mostly, I appreciated the people who took the time to reach out to me with a brief positive comment. 👉 If you notice someone doing good work, spend a minute to let them and their boss (and boss-boss) know. The effort is small, but the amount of positivity generated is big!🧩

I was listening to a serial entrepreneur, and she mentioned the concept of an 𝗜𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗰𝘁 business vs a 𝗟𝗶𝗳𝗲𝘀𝘁𝘆𝗹𝗲 business 👇In an 𝗜𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗰𝘁 business, you’ll often have to sacrifice your personal preferences for the business needs (e.g. growth, reach, profitability).In a 𝗟𝗶𝗳𝗲𝘀𝘁𝘆𝗹𝗲 business, you’ll sacrifice the business needs for your personal preferences (e.g. more time with family, work from anywhere). I never thought of it that way. And it applies to entrepreneurs and employees alike. 👉 There’s no right or wrong answer, but it’s essential to decide which business (or role) you want to run, as it will drive your decision making 🧩

Yesterday a team member of mine celebrated 40 years at the company! 👏Interestingly, her current project is about retiring one of the systems she had implemented in the 1990s! 😃She is a respected team member who is competent, reliable, kind and funny.  We were celebrating her yesterday, and she said the reasons she stuck around were:• From her first job, her boss and peers were welcoming and supportive• She could pursue opportunities she was interested in (𝘣𝘦𝘤𝘢𝘶𝘴𝘦 𝘰𝘧 𝘩𝘦𝘳 𝘢𝘱𝘱𝘳𝘰𝘢𝘤𝘩, 𝘐 𝘮𝘪𝘨𝘩𝘵 𝘢𝘥𝘥) 👉 My takeaway: bosses, team culture and growth opportunities make people stay. 🧩

Over the weekend, I tried an exercise called the “Energy Audit,” and here’s what I’ve learned:🔋 𝗜 𝗳𝗲𝗲𝗹 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗿𝗴𝗶𝘇𝗲𝗱 𝘄𝗵𝗲𝗻:• Learning a new subject• Helping someone• Producing something “tangible”🪫 𝗜 𝗳𝗲𝗲𝗹 𝗹𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗿𝗴𝗶𝘇𝗲𝗱 𝘄𝗵𝗲𝗻:• I don’t have time for “deep work”• I don’t see progress• Generally, when I have little control over my schedulePretty simple but insightful. 👉 If you want to try, you just need two columns on a sheet of paper and 30 minutes of focused time. 🧩

It’s Canadian Thanksgiving today (2nd Monday of October). Its history is complicated, but in a nutshell, it started as a celebration of the harvest, and it's now an opportunity to reflect on the past year's blessings.I explained this to my daughter while we were all in the car together, and we each said what we were grateful for. She said she is grateful for her family, her friends and her toys. That seems about right. Happy Thanksgiving!🧩
Quote I'm pondering:Persuasion is not about getting people to believe what you are saying. 👇Persuasion is about getting people to believe 𝐭𝐡𝐚𝐭 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐛𝐞𝐥𝐢𝐞𝐯𝐞 what you are saying.🧩

“As If Nothing Happened” 👇That’s the title of an art project where Turkish artist Alper Yesiltas has used Artificial Intelligence (AI) to imagine how some celebrities would look today if they were alive. Do you recognize them? I’ll add the names in the comments. 🧩
Did you know? Murphy’s Law states that the best way to get the right answer on the internet is not to ask a question; it's to post the wrong answer.What are some examples where you applied this law?🧩

If you like checklists as I do, it is because of the Zeigarnik effect 👇That’s the psychological tendency to remember an uncompleted task rather than a completed one. It can take a lot of mental bandwidth to remember all unfinished tasks. And a checklist is an easy way to counteract the Zeigsrnik effect and reduce the clutter in your mind. 🧩 Image credit: Doist

“ 𝐓𝐡𝐞 𝐚𝐫𝐞𝐚 𝐰𝐡𝐞𝐫𝐞 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐦𝐨𝐫𝐞 𝐰𝐞𝐥𝐥-𝐞𝐪𝐮𝐢𝐩𝐩𝐞𝐝 𝐭𝐨 𝐬𝐮𝐟𝐟𝐞𝐫 𝐢𝐬 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐰𝐨𝐫𝐤 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐰𝐞𝐫𝐞 𝐦𝐚𝐝𝐞 𝐭𝐨 𝐝𝐨 “ 👇I was listening to the always insightful James Clear (Atomic Habits), and this quote made me think. Here’s why in a nutshell:Most people ask, “Where do I naturally excel?”But every area requires hard work and effort to achieve some level of success. So a better question is, “Where can I handle the pain better than those around me?”A fascinating perspective that I’ve never considered before. 🧩

To all my fellow over-analyzers:I, too, used to think that “𝘒𝘯𝘰𝘸𝘭𝘦𝘥𝘨𝘦 𝘪𝘴 𝘗𝘰𝘸𝘦𝘳.” Now believe that “Action is Power.” 👇Here’s why:If I pay attention to the outcome of my actions and learn from them, I create a data point each time I do something. Whether my action delivered the intended results or not, I have learned something. 👉 So Action is superior to Knowledge. That’s because 𝐀𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐠𝐞𝐧𝐞𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐞𝐬 𝐊𝐧𝐨𝐰𝐥𝐞𝐝𝐠𝐞.  🧩

In July, I had a coffee chat with a newcomer to Canada looking for their first job here 👇I remember looking for my first role in the country. It can be stressful and disorienting: • Your “international” experience is not valued much. • You are playing a new game, and you feel like you don’t know the rules. • It takes determination, discipline and resilience. And someone willing to give you a chance, or at least some guidance. So during the coffee chat in July, I shared my experience and things I’ve learned along the way. I was talking about career paths with a friend recently. A common tread in my roles has been 𝐬𝐲𝐬𝐭𝐞𝐦𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐳𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐝𝐞𝐜𝐢𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧-𝐦𝐚𝐤𝐢𝐧𝐠: from lead scoring to project prioritization. Here’s the approach in a nutshell:• Define in advance what categories you’ll consider and what good looks like• Approach it from a multi-disciplinary or cross-functional perspective • Listen to your gut, and make it explicit. Just because you cannot articulate it yet, it doesn’t mean it’s not valid. It means you need to word it. 🧩

I celebrated 10 years at TELUS this week. Here are 10 of the lessons I've learned along the way 👇1. Your network is your net worth2. Storytelling is the most valuable business skill3. Find a tribe of mentors4. Hiring is the most crucial management task5. If it bothers you, fix it. No matter how small6. Know your derailers7. Make team culture a competitive advantage8. The most recent MBA cohort of my alma mater had their graduation ceremony this week, and yesterday I chatted with one of the graduates. We talked about being a recent graduate looking for their first job in Canada. I remember looking for my first role in the country. It can be stressful. Here’s a summary of what we discussed:• Until when I found a paying gig, my daily job was quite literally Networking and Applying. • Job searching, especially as a recent graduate, is a volume game. I think the ratio of applications to interviews is 50:1. Don’t get discouraged. • Reach out to alums from your school(s) or previous company, people in roles you are interested in etc. Aim to meet with two new people a week. The best time to start your job search was six months ago. The second-best time is today. 🧩

How to prioritize your company's SaaS projects - 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 5.2 𝐁𝐞𝐧𝐞𝐟𝐢𝐭𝐬 𝐡𝐚𝐫𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 👇The last step of the prioritization process should be, in my opinion, confirming that the project delivered the original estimated benefits to the organization.But Benefits harvesting is quite complex for many valid reasons, such for example: • 𝐒𝐜𝐨𝐩𝐞 𝐝𝐞𝐥𝐢𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐞𝐝 𝐢𝐬 𝐝𝐢𝐟𝐟𝐞𝐫𝐞𝐧𝐭 or smaller than the scope considered for benefits estimation; • 𝐌𝐚𝐫𝐤𝐞𝐭 𝐜𝐨𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬 𝐡𝐚𝐯𝐞 𝐜𝐡𝐚𝐧𝐠𝐞𝐝 between when the project was envisioned and when it got delivered; • 𝐀𝐝𝐨𝐩𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐢𝐬 𝐥𝐨𝐰𝐞𝐫 𝐭𝐡𝐚𝐧 𝐞𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐚𝐭𝐞𝐝 due to a lack of proper stakeholder engagement, poor timing, or change fatigue;So it's not a surprise that most organizations struggle with measuring the delivered benefits of their projects. Here are a few things I found helped:• Sign off on estimated benefits. First, have the estimated benefits signed off by a senior leader.• Include adoption success metrics as part of the project vision/charter.• Identify who will be accountable for seeing that the benefits are realized. • Set up some automation to communicate with the parties involved once the project is completed. For example, 3 weeks, 3 months and 12 months after project launch.🧩Click [+ Follow] for more

How to prioritize your company's SaaS projects - 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 5.1 𝐃𝐫𝐢𝐯𝐞 (𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐭𝐫𝐚𝐜𝐤) 𝐚𝐝𝐨𝐩𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧👇When I was supporting a Strategy and Planning team, I had to demonstrate that our approach to project prioritization delivered the organization more bang for each buck than other methods. For most SaaS projects, the Value is created once the target users adopt the new feature or capability. 👉 If Value depends on Adoption, it means that 𝐂𝐡𝐚𝐧𝐠𝐞 𝐌𝐚𝐧𝐚𝐠𝐞𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭 𝐢𝐬 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐚𝐫𝐞𝐧𝐚 𝐰𝐡𝐞𝐫𝐞 𝐕𝐚𝐥𝐮𝐞 𝐢𝐬 𝐜𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐭𝐞𝐝. Change Management is the people side of any organizational change, the discipline which guides how we prepare individuals to adopt the change to drive organizational outcomes. We can say that Project Management prepares the Solution for the Organization, while Change Management prepares the Organization for the Solution.In my experience, a Strategy team is rarely accountable for Adoption - but my point is that 𝐢𝐟 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐬𝐞𝐫𝐢𝐨𝐮𝐬 𝐚𝐛𝐨𝐮𝐭 𝐩𝐫𝐢𝐨𝐫𝐢𝐭𝐢𝐳𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧, 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐧𝐞𝐞𝐝 𝐭𝐨 𝐞𝐧𝐬𝐮𝐫𝐞 𝐬𝐨𝐦𝐞𝐨𝐧𝐞 𝐢𝐬 𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐩𝐨𝐧𝐬𝐢𝐛𝐥𝐞 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐝𝐫𝐢𝐯𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐚𝐝𝐨𝐩𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧. 🧩Click [+ Follow] for more

My parents’ digital signage company grew in its first ten years because, in 1978, my father patented a wireless infrared remote while everyone else had to use meters of cables. So I always thought the role of patents is to reward innovation, but Elon Musk has a very different take:“ 𝘞𝘦 𝘥𝘰𝘯’𝘵 𝘱𝘢𝘵𝘦𝘯𝘵 𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘯𝘨𝘴. 𝘗𝘢𝘵𝘦𝘯𝘵𝘴 𝘢𝘳𝘦 𝘧𝘰𝘳 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘸𝘦𝘢𝘬. 𝘗𝘢𝘵𝘦𝘯𝘵𝘴 𝘢𝘳𝘦 𝘨𝘦𝘯𝘦𝘳𝘢𝘭𝘭𝘺 𝘶𝘴𝘦𝘥 𝘢𝘴 𝘢 𝘣𝘭𝘰𝘤𝘬𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘵𝘦𝘤𝘩𝘯𝘪𝘲𝘶𝘦. 𝘛𝘩𝘦𝘺 𝘢𝘳𝘦 𝘭𝘪𝘬𝘦 𝘶𝘴𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘭𝘢𝘯𝘥𝘮𝘪𝘯𝘦𝘴 𝘪𝘯 𝘸𝘢𝘳𝘧𝘢𝘳𝘦. 𝘛𝘩𝘦𝘺 𝘥𝘰𝘯’𝘵 𝘩𝘦𝘭𝘱 𝘢𝘥𝘷𝘢𝘯𝘤𝘦 𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘯𝘨𝘴. 𝘛𝘩𝘦𝘺 𝘫𝘶𝘴𝘵 𝘴𝘵𝘰𝘱 𝘰𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘳𝘴 𝘧𝘳𝘰𝘮 𝘧𝘰𝘭𝘭𝘰𝘸𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘺𝘰𝘶. 𝘔𝘰𝘴𝘵 𝘱𝘢𝘵𝘦𝘯𝘵𝘴 𝘢𝘳𝘦 𝘉𝘚. “And I have to admit he has a point. I can see both sides of the argument. I’m curious, what does LinkedIn think?🧩

How to prioritize your company's SaaS projects - 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 5.0 𝐁𝐞𝐧𝐞𝐟𝐢𝐭𝐬 𝐑𝐞𝐚𝐥𝐢𝐳𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐌𝐚𝐧𝐚𝐠𝐞𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭👇Organizations invest time and resources in delivering projects because they expect the value created will drive the business forward. This might sound obvious, but here are a couple of challenges I’ve found in my experience:👉 𝐀𝐝𝐨𝐩𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐜𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐭𝐞𝐬 𝐕𝐚𝐥𝐮𝐞. Completing the project doesn’t in itself create value. In most SaaS projects, the value is created once the target users adopt the new feature or capability. And completing the project doesn’t automatically drive adoption—quite the opposite. Often, I’ve seen resistance. 👉 𝐁𝐞𝐧𝐞𝐟𝐢𝐭𝐬 𝐡𝐚𝐫𝐯𝐞𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐢𝐬 𝐡𝐚𝐫𝐝. Most organizations are not very good at measuring the benefits of their projects.We might lack clear KPIs. Or the ability to compare actual benefits to what was estimated a year ago. Or no one might have a clear responsibility for seeing that the project benefits are realized. In the next few days, I'll share what I have found helpful in these areas.  🧩Click [+ Follow] for more  #BusinessValueScore #Framework

How to prioritize your company's SaaS projects - 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 4.3 𝐁𝐮𝐢𝐥𝐝 𝐚 𝐩𝐥𝐚𝐲𝐛𝐨𝐨𝐤 👇Breaking down projects into manageable chunks and documenting a checklist of deliverables will provide much clarity.The only thing missing is now the instructions to complete each of those deliverables—a playbook.A business playbook contains all the pieces and parts that make up our organization's go-to approach for getting things done. It includes process workflows, standard operating procedures, roles and responsibilities, and milestones that shape a consistent response—the play.The value of a playbook is that having repeatable and scalable processes will reduce time spent training, encourages independence and autonomy of our team members, saves time and mistakes, and ensures consistent results for our stakeholders and customers.If you are in a Strategy and Planning role, it probably means you are not accountable for project delivery, so creating a playbook is not your responsibility.But in my experience, it is incredibly helpful.🧩Click [+ Follow] for more  #BusinessValueScore #Framework

How to prioritize your company's SaaS projects - 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 4.2 𝐂𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐚 𝐭𝐚𝐬𝐤 𝐢𝐧𝐯𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐨𝐫𝐲 👇No matter how big or small the project is, in my experience the most effective way to create clarity and improve reporting is by breaking them down into something more manageable.We generally break down the project into big chunks and then break those down even more into smaller pieces that become our deliverables. A checklist of deliverables will provide a lot of clarity. 𝐀𝐧𝐝 𝐜𝐥𝐚𝐫𝐢𝐭𝐲 𝐠𝐞𝐧𝐞𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐞𝐬 𝐬𝐩𝐞𝐞𝐝.One of the best recent examples I have witnessed was when my team had to break down our responsibilities. After some discussions, we identified five key milestones, each with 8-12 tasks, for a total of over 60 deliverables.Now 60 deliverables might seem daunting, but whether we document them or not, we are still accountable for delivering them. So why not list them all?If you are in a Strategy and Planning role it probably means you are not accountable for project delivery, so creating a checklist is not your responsibility.But in my experience, it was helpful to ask my delivery partners to create one and share it with me so I could better understand the amount of effort involved and how things were progressing.🧩Click [+ Follow] for more  #BusinessValueScore #Framework

How to prioritize your company's SaaS projects - 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 4.1 𝐓𝐫𝐚𝐜𝐤 𝐩𝐫𝐨𝐣𝐞𝐜𝐭𝐬' 𝐬𝐭𝐚𝐭𝐮𝐬 👇Tracking a project's status throughout the software delivery lifecycle (SDLC) sounds obvious, but it can be tricky when discussing a SaaS project with multiple Agile releases over several months.That's because different Work Packages can be in flight simultaneously but in various stages of the SDLC. So it becomes difficult to understand and communicate the status of the overall project succinctly.One approach is to track each single work package independently. In this case, it's easier to communicate status quickly (e.g. Red, Green or Yellow), but we lose the holistic view of the project.My approach was to visualize the status of each of the various stages of the software delivery lifecycle. Like in the example in the screenshot. My idea was to communicate both Progress (i.e. how much we have done) and Status (i.e. how things are going now).𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐠𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐬 𝐢𝐬 𝐚 𝐩𝐞𝐫𝐜𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐚𝐠𝐞 completion between 0% and 100% (in my case, it was tracked with 25% increments for simplicity).𝐒𝐭𝐚𝐭𝐮𝐬 𝐢𝐬 𝐜𝐨𝐥𝐨𝐮𝐫-𝐜𝐨𝐝𝐞𝐝 based on the risks or delays (or lack thereof) we are experiencing this week.I found this view was too detailed for senior leaders but valuable for the Planning and Delivery teams.🧩Click [+ Follow] for more#BusinessValueScore #Framework

I learned today that there are two types of professional drivers (e.g. Formula 1, Nascar): a blue driver 🔵 and a red driver 🔴.When you start racing, you start as one of these two, based on your personality.A 🔵 driver is someone who goes out on the track for the first time and builds up to it. Lap by lap, they get closer and closer to the limit and then reach it. One example could be Valtteri Bottas.A 🔴 driver just goes flat out, goes over the limit first and then dials it back. One example could be Max Verstappen.The ideal is a purple driver 🟣. Someone that can switch from one approach to the other based on the current needs. One example, could be Lewis Hamilton.🧩

We always knew, but more and more evidence seems to support how vital sleep is for a healthy lifestyle. 🧩

How to prioritize your company's SaaS projects - 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 4.0 𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐣𝐞𝐜𝐭 𝐃𝐞𝐥𝐢𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐲 👇If you, like me at one point, are in a position to prioritize hundreds of SaaS projects, you are likely in a Strategy and Planning role.These roles are pretty distant from the actual project delivery and can honestly feel quite abstract.I found a few things that helped me to stay closer to and feel more connected with the project delivery aspect:• 𝐓𝐫𝐚𝐜𝐤 𝐩𝐫𝐨𝐣𝐞𝐜𝐭𝐬' 𝐬𝐭𝐚𝐭𝐮𝐬 𝐭𝐡𝐫𝐨𝐮𝐠𝐡𝐨𝐮𝐭 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐬𝐨𝐟𝐭𝐰𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐝𝐞𝐥𝐢𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐲 𝐥𝐢𝐟𝐞𝐜𝐲𝐜𝐥𝐞. Tracking status sounds obvious, but it can be tricky when discussing a SaaS project with multiple Agile releases over several months.• 𝐂𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐚 𝐭𝐚𝐬𝐤 𝐢𝐧𝐯𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐨𝐫𝐲, 𝐧𝐨 𝐦𝐚𝐭𝐭𝐞𝐫 𝐡𝐨𝐰 𝐥𝐨𝐧𝐠.  Some people hate checklists. Personally, I like them. They provide clarity and allow me to focus my mental energy on new problems instead of rethinking old ones.• 𝐁𝐮𝐢𝐥𝐝 𝐚 𝐩𝐥𝐚𝐲𝐛𝐨𝐨𝐤 𝐛𝐚𝐬𝐞𝐝 𝐨𝐧 𝐛𝐞𝐬𝐭 𝐩𝐫𝐚𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐜𝐞𝐬. I used to think naively that most SaaS projects were somewhat similar. I now believe that the different scope, personalities, challenges, ecosystems and timing make each project unique.In the next few days, I'll share what I have found helpful in these areas.  🧩Click [+ Follow] for more  #BusinessValueScore #Framework

How to prioritize your company's SaaS projects - 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 3.2 𝐕𝐢𝐬𝐮𝐚𝐥𝐬 𝐭𝐨 𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐦𝐮𝐧𝐢𝐜𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐩𝐥𝐞𝐱 𝐢𝐧𝐟𝐨𝐫𝐦𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 👇For a long time, I underestimated visuals' important role in influencing behavior in a business setting (vs dry spreadsheets and tables).I think it goes back to the importance of storytelling mentioned in a previous post. Here are a few of my lessons learned:• 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐚𝐥 𝐥𝐢𝐤𝐞 𝐚𝐧 𝐚𝐫𝐭𝐢𝐬𝐭. It doesn't mean plagiarising. But instead, I studied, remixed, and mashed up the creative visuals I found helpful. • 𝐆𝐞𝐭 𝐟𝐞𝐞𝐝𝐛𝐚𝐜𝐤. No matter how good I thought my visual was, a trusted colleague expert in Communication could always find a way to improve it, usually by removing something.• 𝐈𝐧𝐭𝐫𝐨𝐝𝐮𝐜𝐞 𝐧𝐞𝐰 𝐯𝐢𝐬𝐮𝐚𝐥𝐬 𝐠𝐫𝐚𝐝𝐮𝐚𝐥𝐥𝐲. A unique and better way of presenting information can be confusing if your audience is used to seeing a specific format and template.🧩Click [+ Follow] for more  #BusinessValueScore #Framework

How to prioritize your company’s SaaS projects - 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 3.1𝐁 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐞𝐫𝐂𝐨‘𝐬 𝐏𝐚𝐢𝐧𝐟𝐮𝐥 𝐋𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐨𝐧𝐬 (𝐜𝐨𝐧𝐭’𝐝)👇 I’ve posted about the pitfalls of running a SteerCo meeting. Here is my third lesson learned. I learned that Storytelling is the most important skill one can develop. It can make you formidable at your job.• 𝐋𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐨𝐧 #3 - 𝐒𝐭𝐨𝐫𝐲𝐭𝐞𝐥𝐥𝐢𝐧𝐠 Storytelling starts with defining the strategy first, the desired outcome, and the content only comes second. Getting things done in any large organization requires cross-departmental cooperation. To get collaboration, we need to understand the motivations of our partners and what’s driving their business. And then, we can build a narrative that gains support and drives our vision. Some people are natural storytellers. For the rest of us, the only way to get better is to practice, practice, practice. So, if I had to do it again, I would spend more time learning about my stakeholder's drivers and developing my storytelling skills.🧩Click [+ Follow] for more  #BusinessValueScore #Framework
“𝐕𝐚𝐥𝐮𝐞𝐬 𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐝𝐞𝐜𝐢𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧-𝐦𝐚𝐤𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐟𝐢𝐥𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐬.”I heard this sentence today, and I thought it was as relevant in business as it is in personal matters. 🧩

How to prioritize your company’s SaaS projects - 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 3.1𝐁 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐞𝐫𝐂𝐨‘𝐬 𝐏𝐚𝐢𝐧𝐟𝐮𝐥 𝐋𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐨𝐧𝐬 (𝐜𝐨𝐧𝐭’𝐝)👇 • 𝐋𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐨𝐧 #2 - 𝐃𝐞𝐜𝐢𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐌𝐚𝐤𝐢𝐧𝐠Agreeing on the relative priority of multiple high-stakes projects with complex specs with a large number of participants was difficult. How we make decisions on the SteerCo is critical to its success and efficacy. And the decision-making approach is very much influenced by the company culture. In our case, decisions were made mainly by consensus, which can be time-consuming when compared, for example, to a voting system of some sort. I found that stating precisely what decision we needed to make at the beginning of the SteerCo helped frame the discussion and reduced (although not eliminated) the chance of ending the meeting with no clear decision. If I had to do it again, I would consider having a smaller group of participants on the SteerCo. And I would be more deliberate about including the right senior leadership level (e.g. Directors vs VPs) depending on the decision. 🧩Click [+ Follow] for more  #BusinessValueScore #Framework

How to prioritize your company’s SaaS projects - 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 3.1B 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐞𝐫𝐂𝐨‘𝐬 𝐏𝐚𝐢𝐧𝐟𝐮𝐥 𝐋𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐨𝐧𝐬👇Yesterday I discussed the pitfalls of running a SteerCo meeting. Today I’m starting to share the lessons I learned. Running effective and successful SteerCo Meetings is a valuable skill and deserves its series of posts.There are hundreds of articles about SteerCo's best practices, and I’m sure there are books about it. I haven’t read them. But here is what I’ve understood from direct experience:  • 𝐋𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐨𝐧 #1 𝐏𝐫𝐞-𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐝 𝐜𝐨𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐧𝐭 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐬𝐭𝐚𝐤𝐞𝐡𝐨𝐥𝐝𝐞𝐫𝐬Large projects are complex; they require lots of change management, starting from the top. I found that reviewing with the Directors the content of the meeting agenda and stating my goals and recommendations in advance drove better outcomes. So why not just do it all the time? Because things move fast and time available in calendars is limited. So it wasn’t always possible to prep. Or not with everyone. If I had to do it again, I would hire 1 or 2 Senior Program Managers to help me with Directors SteerCo Meetings prep and management. 🧩Click [+ Follow] for more  #BusinessValueScore #Framework

How to prioritize your company’s SaaS projects - 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 3.1A 𝐏𝐢𝐭𝐟𝐚𝐥𝐥𝐬 𝐨𝐟 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐞𝐫𝐂𝐨 𝐌𝐞𝐞𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠𝐬👇Running effective and successful SteerCo Meetings is quite tricky. Here are some of the reasons why: • 𝐎𝐧𝐠𝐨𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐩𝐚𝐫𝐭𝐢𝐜𝐢𝐩𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧. Our Director SteerCo got good attendance in the first few months, but after a while, someone started sending their delegates. This created a vicious circle where eventually, there would only be delegates on the call, which meant the SteerCo had lost its purpose. • 𝐄𝐧𝐠𝐚𝐠𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐜𝐨𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐧𝐭. Keeping the audience engaged starts with creating relevant and engaging content for everyone. This can be challenging when some of the projects are not important or not top of mind to some participants. • 𝐀𝐜𝐡𝐢𝐞𝐯𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐜𝐨𝐧𝐬𝐞𝐧𝐬𝐮𝐬. One of the purposes of a SteerCo is to make decisions. Enabling Directors to make decisions starts with conveying complex information succinctly.Communicating effectively to a diverse audience with different levels of familiarity with each project can be a difficult balance to strike. 👉 Tomorrow I’ll share some lessons I’ve learned (the hard way) about managing SteerCos. 🧩Click [+ Follow] for more  #BusinessValueScore #Framework

How to prioritize your company’s SaaS projects - 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 3.1 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐞𝐫𝐂𝐨 𝐌𝐞𝐞𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠𝐬👇The Steering Committee, or SteerCo, is an advisory body, often part of project governance. When managing the project funnel, we grouped the initiatives into three main groups: small, medium and large. Small and medium-sized initiatives didn’t need a SteerCo. We determined their priority almost exclusively based on the Business Value Score (BVS) calculated in step 2.2. For large initiatives, the BVS was just a way to identify which projects we should bring in front of the SteerCo for discussion. Once the project was on the SteerCo shortlist, the BVS didn’t matter much anymore, other than providing more context around costs and effort estimation if required. The SteerCo Meeting was an opportunity for the leadership of the different Business groups to get a holistic view of all the projects and discuss their relative priority.  🧩Click [+ Follow] for more  #BusinessValueScore #Framework

How to prioritize your company’s SaaS projects - 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 3.0 𝐆𝐨𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐧𝐚𝐧𝐜𝐞👇Sizing the projects and ranking them was an essential step in our selection process, but not the final one. In my experience, the Business teams might not be aware of each other's initiatives, and the team managing the project funnel might be the only one with a holistic view of what’s happening in the organization. So, we had to raise awareness by bringing this holistic view back to the different business groups, especially when discussing the most transformational initiatives. For the organization to make an informed decision, it was essential that we established the proper forums and communicated a lot of information quickly and effectively. Governance is the most critical of the steps and the most difficult to get right. In the next few days, I’ll review how we went about it and what lessons we learned along the way. 🧩Click [+ Follow] for more  #BusinessValueScore #Framework

Another caveat about benefits estimates is their reliability. Even the most thorough business cases are based on lots of assumptions. 👇How to prioritize your company’s SaaS projects - 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 2.4 𝐁𝐞𝐧𝐞𝐟𝐢𝐭𝐬 𝐄𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐚𝐭𝐞𝐬 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐒𝐢𝐠𝐧𝐨𝐟𝐟 (𝐜𝐨𝐧𝐭’𝐝)My experience has been that although transformational projects on paper are more compelling than targeted initiatives, they tend to deliver less value than expected.This can be due to a series of factors, such as: • The stakeholders estimating the correct value, to begin with• The product team defining the problem and the scope clearly • The IT teams delivering the desired solution promptly • The organization handling the level of change management required💡 On the other side, smaller and more local initiatives are, in my experience, more accurate in their benefits predictions. • People already use the functionality, so there are reliable usage and adoption stats (vs assumptions)• The problem is smaller and easier to identify and describe• The solution is less complex to implement and more likely to be delivered on time and specs• The change management is incremental, and adoption is more likely 👉 Transformational initiatives are critical to driving growth, and I’m not advocating we eliminate them. But there is, in my experience, a ton of 𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐥 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐩𝐨𝐮𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐯𝐚𝐥𝐮𝐞 (𝐯𝐬 𝐞𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐚𝐭𝐞𝐝 𝐯𝐚𝐥𝐮𝐞) in medium-sized initiatives that get deprioritized too early. 🧩Click [+ Follow] for more  #BusinessValueScore #Framework

How to prioritize your company’s SaaS projects - 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 2.4 𝐁𝐞𝐧𝐞𝐟𝐢𝐭𝐬 𝐄𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐚𝐭𝐞𝐬 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐒𝐢𝐠𝐧𝐨𝐟𝐟👇A significant component of project prioritization is the estimate of the benefits. It does make sense to prioritize the projects with the most robust business case. ⚠️ In my experience, though, there is one crucial caveat:Building a business case that includes ROI and IRR calculations takes time, skills and effort. And the problem with that is not all the business units in the company have strategy managers or performance analysts on staff to build one. The result is that some business units won’t submit a project not because it wouldn’t drive lot of value but simply because they don’t have the staff to create a compelling business case.  For those of us managing a project funnel, this means that 𝐢𝐧𝐬𝐭𝐞𝐚𝐝 𝐨𝐟 𝐩𝐫𝐢𝐨𝐫𝐢𝐭𝐢𝐳𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐰𝐡𝐚𝐭’𝐬 𝐦𝐨𝐬𝐭 𝐢𝐦𝐩𝐨𝐫𝐭𝐚𝐧𝐭 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐩𝐚𝐧𝐲, 𝐰𝐞 𝐫𝐢𝐬𝐤 𝐩𝐫𝐢𝐨𝐫𝐢𝐭𝐢𝐳𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐰𝐡𝐢𝐜𝐡 𝐭𝐞𝐚𝐦 𝐢𝐬 𝐛𝐞𝐭𝐭𝐞𝐫 𝐚𝐭 𝐛𝐮𝐢𝐥𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐛𝐮𝐬𝐢𝐧𝐞𝐬𝐬 𝐜𝐚𝐬𝐞𝐬. Business cases play a critical role in driving a company’s decisions, and I’m not advocating we eliminate them. But make sure to understand what’s being left out when we exclusively use that lens. 🧩Click [+ Follow] for more  #BusinessValueScore #Framework

How to prioritize your company’s SaaS projects - 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 2.3 (𝐜𝐨𝐧𝐭’𝐝) 𝐇𝐨𝐬𝐭 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐫𝐢𝐠𝐡𝐭 𝐟𝐨𝐫𝐮𝐦𝐬 👇Once we had the estimator tool in place, it was time to figure out how to best use people’s time. Here is how we organized our approach: we had multiple forums, each dedicated to addressing a specific type of request.  • 𝐎𝐧 𝐌𝐨𝐧𝐝𝐚𝐲𝐬, a Business System Analyst would review our projects funnel and address all the “smaller enhancements.” We also called them BAU (Business as Usual) enhancements. These are relatively small projects. In our case, we defined BAU enhancements as projects that would (1) impact one single SaaS platform, (2) be less than two person-weeks of an overall effort and (3) require configuration only (i.e. no custom development). • 𝐎𝐧 𝐓𝐮𝐞𝐬𝐝𝐚𝐲𝐬, we would have a second forum to review anything bigger than a BAU enhancement. We aimed to estimate each “medium size” project, which we defined as impacting one single platform but requiring more than two weeks of effort or some custom development. On this second forum, we would have not only the Business System Analyst but also a Solution Architect to provide the technical perspective and a Business Consultant to represent the stakeholders. We would not invite the project submitters just yet. • 𝐅𝐢𝐧𝐚𝐥𝐥𝐲, 𝐨𝐧 𝐖𝐞𝐝𝐧𝐞𝐬𝐝𝐚𝐲𝐬, we would host a larger forum to discuss all projects that were impacting more than one SaaS platform. Here we estimated the effort for more transformational initiatives with multiple Solution Architects and Business Consultants from different groups. We often invite the project submitter to provide an overview of the request. 🧩 Click [+ Follow] for more  #BusinessValueScore #Framework

If you are following this mini-series on SaaS project sizing, here’s something important to clarify: the difference between DCUT and SDLC 👇How to prioritize your company’s SaaS projects - 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 2.3 𝐄𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐓𝐨𝐨𝐥𝐬 (𝐜𝐨𝐧𝐭’𝐝)The difference between DCUT and SDLC was the source of much confusion for us early on. Here’s how I would explain it: • 𝐃𝐂𝐔𝐓 𝐬𝐭𝐚𝐧𝐝𝐬 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐃𝐞𝐬𝐢𝐠𝐧, 𝐂𝐨𝐝𝐞 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐔𝐧𝐢𝐭 𝐓𝐞𝐬𝐭. DCUT estimation comprises only those three aspects of software development, and it does NOT consider any supporting activity, such as project management, quality assurance, environment management and other shared services. Critically, DCUT is what the technical and IT delivery teams are generally estimating. • 𝐒𝐃𝐋𝐂 𝐬𝐭𝐚𝐧𝐝𝐬 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐒𝐨𝐟𝐭𝐰𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐃𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐥𝐨𝐩𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭 𝐋𝐢𝐟𝐞 𝐂𝐲𝐜𝐥𝐞. SDLC estimates comprise all the aspects of the end-to-end software development cycle, including supporting activities and shared services, such as release management. SDLC is what the stakeholders generally think it’s being estimated. And the difference can be pretty staggering. I wouldn’t be surprised if DCUT represented only 50% or even 40% of the overall SDLC effort. This discrepancy can obviously have a significant impact on the accuracy of cost estimates. So make sure to understand what’s being estimated. 🧩Click [+ Follow] for more  #BusinessValueScore #Framework

How to prioritize your company’s SaaS projects - 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 2.3 𝐀𝐬𝐬𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭 𝐓𝐨𝐨𝐥𝐬👇To provide timely and (somewhat) accurate estimates, we built our own estimator tools. This is how:• 𝐖𝐞 𝐥𝐢𝐬𝐭𝐞𝐝 𝐚𝐥𝐥 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐚𝐬𝐩𝐞𝐜𝐭𝐬 we needed to consider when prioritizing projects against each other - for example, Cost, but also Projects Complexity, Likelihood of Adoption, Stakeholders Alignment etc. • 𝐖𝐞 𝐚𝐠𝐫𝐞𝐞𝐝 𝐨𝐧 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐝𝐞𝐟𝐢𝐧𝐢𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬 of our sizing. For example, how do we define Small, Medium and Large? Or High, Medium, Low? Achieving consensus around these terms took longer than we expected. • 𝐖𝐞 𝐛𝐮𝐢𝐥𝐭 𝐚𝐧 𝐞𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐚𝐭𝐨𝐫 for quick and dirty high-level assessments (where we were only looking for an order of magnitude) and another for more precise and time-intensive estimates. • 𝐖𝐞 𝐤𝐞𝐩𝐭 𝐢𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 each time we encountered a project that exposed a weakness in our approach. Those little improvements were frequent at first, became rare later on, and compounded until the estimator became quite sophisticated.• 𝐖𝐞 𝐥𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐧𝐞𝐝 𝐭𝐡𝐚𝐭 𝐞𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐢𝐬 𝐚𝐧 𝐢𝐦𝐩𝐞𝐫𝐟𝐞𝐜𝐭 𝐝𝐢𝐬𝐜𝐢𝐩𝐥𝐢𝐧𝐞. Some estimates might be completely wrong at first for various reasons. The goal is to keep improving on all the aspects we can control or at least influence. 🧩Click [+ Follow] for more  #BusinessValueScore #Framework

How to prioritize your company’s SaaS projects - 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 2.2 𝐁𝐮𝐬𝐢𝐧𝐞𝐬𝐬 𝐕𝐚𝐥𝐮𝐞 𝐒𝐜𝐨𝐫𝐞👇The Business Value Score (BVS) it’s a number between 1 and 100 that allows us to compare the relative priority of different projects in a single funnel. For example, a 95% BVS is a higher priority than a 45% BVS.In a nutshell, it’s about identifying the critical dimensions determining project priority and then scoring each project against them. For example, one dimension could be “Alignment to the Company’s business priorities,” and the scale could be “High, Medium, Low.” In my previous role, we identified ten dimensions, so we calculated the BVS by answering ten questions. The project requestor provided some of the answers (e.g. Estimated Benefits?), and the technology teams the others (e.g. Technical Complexity?). 🧩Click [+ Follow] for more  #BusinessValueScore #Framework

How to prioritize your company’s SaaS projects - 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 2.1 𝐂𝐨𝐬𝐭 𝐀𝐬𝐬𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭👇Our stakeholders take the time to fill out the intake form (step 1.1) to get back an estimate of how much it would cost to develop their new functionality. The problem with cost estimates is that they can take a lot of time and effort to create and still be wildly inaccurate ⚠️Our approach to mitigate both these problems was the following:• 𝐂𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐚 𝐜𝐡𝐞𝐜𝐤𝐥𝐢𝐬𝐭 𝐨𝐟 𝐚𝐥𝐥 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐚𝐬𝐩𝐞𝐜𝐭𝐬 𝐨𝐟 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐭𝐞𝐜𝐡𝐧𝐢𝐜𝐚𝐥 𝐢𝐦𝐩𝐥𝐞𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧. This list grew over time and became more sophisticated, but the original list was just 8-10 items.These are completely dependent on the SaaS platform, but some examples could be: Data Model changes (e.g. new objects); Declarative changes (e.g. new sharing rules); Programmatic changes (e.g. new API);• 𝐓𝐡𝐞𝐧 𝐢𝐝𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐟𝐲 𝐩𝐫𝐞𝐝𝐞𝐟𝐢𝐧𝐞𝐝 𝐚𝐧𝐬𝐰𝐞𝐫 𝐯𝐚𝐥𝐮𝐞𝐬 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐞𝐚𝐜𝐡 𝐨𝐟 𝐭𝐡𝐨𝐬𝐞 𝐭𝐞𝐜𝐡𝐧𝐢𝐜𝐚𝐥 𝐞𝐥𝐞𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬. For example, “High - Medium - Low” or “ Yes - No.” We also borrowed the Fibonacci scale from the Agile world - i.e. a sequence of numbers used for estimating the relative effort size: 0, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13, 20, 40 and 100.👉 The checklist ensured we did not miss any critical aspect of the assessment. And the pre-defined options/answers were helpful to speed up the evaluation. 🧩Click [+ Follow] for more  #BusinessValueScore #Framework

How to prioritize your company’s SaaS projects - 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 2.0 𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐣𝐞𝐜𝐭 𝐑𝐚𝐧𝐤𝐢𝐧𝐠 👇After receiving the project submissions, we had a system to assess and rank them. There are a few principles we needed to guide our approach to be successful: • We need a repeatable approach that improves our likelihood of making the right decision• We need an approach that can keep up with the volume of requests (100s per year)• That can do so by providing timely and accurate effort/cost estimates back to our stakeholders • And that makes efficient use of the time of technical people in high demand • A tool that allow us to “compare apples with oranges” (i.e. minor enhancements 🍎 vs transformational initiatives 🍊)• Finally, we need to be able to justify our choices and recommendations to business stakeholders and senior leadershipIn the next few days, let’s review how to do that in practice. 🧩Click [+ Follow] for more  #BusinessValueScore #Framework

When my team's mandate was to prioritize 100s of SaaS projects a year, this is what we came up with👇The first step of this system is: 1.0 𝐅𝐫𝐨𝐧𝐭 𝐃𝐨𝐨𝐫 𝐌𝐚𝐧𝐚𝐠𝐞𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭 A “Front Door,” in this context, is the main entrance to our project funnel. The main challenge this front door is trying to solve is the inconsistency in project submissions. There are two aspects to the front door:👉 𝐓𝐡𝐞 𝐈𝐧𝐭𝐚𝐤𝐞 𝐅𝐨𝐫𝐦 is a web form for our business stakeholders to submit high-level details about their project to get a cost assessment. A few considerations when selecting the fields and questions to include in the form:- To avoid the proliferation of “nice to know” questions, we ask only for info that is critical to making an assessment - Where possible, we present a list of predefined options, like drop-down, radio boxes or multiple choice options- We provide the submitter with the opportunity to provide business context via free text fields and attachments (e.g. screenshots etc.) 👉 𝐓𝐡𝐞 𝐄𝐧𝐠𝐚𝐠𝐞𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭 𝐑𝐮𝐥𝐞𝐬 are conditions for submitting the form and engaging the resources required to make the cost assessment (e.g. technical architects etc.) A few considerations about engagement rules:- Depending on the situation, we might want to allow every user of our tool or platform to submit a new request. - In other cases, we might want only a representative or business prime for each stakeholders’ group to submit a new project. - Overall, we are trying to strike a balance. We don’t want to put up too many barriers to project submission. Yet, we don’t want a single-paragraph by a random person to be sufficient to engage multiple technical resources in high demand. 🧩Click [+ Follow] for more  #BusinessValueScore #Framework

Quote I’m pondering, from Petrarch (scholar and poet, born in 1304):Ut stomachis sic ingeniis nausea sepius nocuit quam fames. Which means:𝐋𝐢𝐤𝐞 𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐬𝐭𝐨𝐦𝐚𝐜𝐡𝐬, 𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐦𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐬 𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐡𝐮𝐫𝐭 𝐦𝐨𝐫𝐞 𝐨𝐟𝐭𝐞𝐧 𝐛𝐲 𝐨𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐭𝐡𝐚𝐧 𝐡𝐮𝐧𝐠𝐞𝐫.I guess over-information is not as recent a phenomenon as I thought. 🧩

My daughter needs a spacer, so we have been looking for orthodontists.We have met with two. Both seemed competent and price aligned. One talked directly to me about the steps involved. The other one had a welcome message with my daughter’s name on a massive screen. She was explicitly promised she’ll feel no pain ever in the studio. They had a wheel of fortune where she won a small prize before we left. Guess which one she/we picked. Assuming they are both legitimate and reasonably priced studios, my consideration was: 👉 Which one will not require a lengthy and painful discussion with my daughter before each visit for the next few years?And they nailed it. A lesson I’m taking away: know who’s your (real) customer and understand what’s driving their decision. 🧩

Domino’s Pizza filed for bankruptcy in 🇮🇹 this week. I’ve lived abroad for the past 12 years, so I was surprised to learn they even had an Italian subsidiary. I noticed quite a few ironic remarks from media outlets and readers alike. A couple made me chuckle:“ Domino’s Pizza closed its Italian stores, with the American fast-food outlet having inexplicably failed to win over the country that invented the pie with its own, stodgy version. “ - The Economist“ In a trading update issued in April, it blamed the poor sales performance on increased competition from “‘mom and pop’ restaurants” - Financial Times“ Next time you're afraid to share ideas, remember someone once said in a meeting: Let’s open a Domino’s in Italy. ” - a reader 🧩

Alexis Pappas is an athlete, and she was struggling with a particularly challenging workout one day. Her coach - an Olympian athlete - told her it was ok. It was 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐑𝐮𝐥𝐞 𝐨𝐟 𝐓𝐡𝐢𝐫𝐝𝐬:“ When you are chasing a dream or doing anything hard, you are meant to feel good a third of the time, okay a third of the time and crappy a third of the time. If you feel roughly in those ratios, you are doing fine, and today was just the crappy day along your dream chasing. “Good advice about mindset from an elite athlete for anyone doing something difficult 💪If you always feel too good, you're not pushing yourself enough. And if you always feel too tired, you might be burning out. She went on to represent Greece at the 2016 Olympics in Rio, setting the national record for the 10k run. 🧩

I learned recently about the concept of Return On Attention (ROA). Attention is a limited resource. And we need it to manage a seemingly unlimited amount of information. So the question becomes: 👉 Is this topic/issue/content important enough to deserve the amount of attention I’m giving it?🧩

About 1.7M books are published every year in the world. 👇Assuming I could read one book a week for 80 years, that’d be about 4000 books in my lifetime.  That’s 0.002% of all books published this year alone. Luckily, most books are not worth reading. Or they are one single idea stretched for 300 pages. 👉 Moral of the story: I used to want to read as many books as possible. Now I want to re-read a few books multiple times. 🧩

Here’s my own experience for anyone that has Alexander’s same question 👇In the screenshot is the comment on a recent post I wrote about how self-awareness can help candidates to find their niche. Some people have a clear vision and path early on. Others have to discover it along the way. Here are a couple of things that I found helpful:𝐈 𝐰𝐨𝐫𝐤𝐞𝐝 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐚 𝐬𝐦𝐚𝐥𝐥 𝐛𝐮𝐬𝐢𝐧𝐞𝐬𝐬 𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐥𝐲 𝐢𝐧 𝐦𝐲 𝐜𝐚𝐫𝐞𝐞𝐫. It was helpful to get somewhat involved in all the different aspects of the company. Like a buffet, it helped to sample different things before picking one. I’d recommend every recent graduate to work for a small business for a few years. 𝐈 𝐭𝐨𝐨𝐤 𝐬𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐚𝐥 𝐬𝐜𝐢𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐟𝐢𝐜𝐚𝐥𝐥𝐲 𝐛𝐚𝐬𝐞𝐝 𝐩𝐬𝐲𝐜𝐡𝐨𝐥𝐨𝐠𝐢𝐜𝐚𝐥, 𝐛𝐞𝐡𝐚𝐯𝐢𝐨𝐮𝐫𝐚𝐥 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐚𝐭𝐭𝐢𝐭𝐮𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐚𝐥 𝐭𝐞𝐬𝐭𝐬. None of them was 100% accurate, but they were 70% to 80%, I’d say. I took what was spot on and discarded what was entirely off. It helped me identify some blind spots, and most of all, it gave me the language and the terminology to explain better what I do. 𝐈 𝐥𝐢𝐬𝐭𝐞𝐝 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐚𝐜𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐩𝐥𝐢𝐬𝐡𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬 𝐈 𝐰𝐚𝐬 𝐦𝐨𝐬𝐭 𝐩𝐫𝐨𝐮𝐝 𝐨𝐟 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐧 𝐥𝐨𝐨𝐤𝐞𝐝 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐦𝐨𝐧 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐦𝐞𝐬. It turns out I enjoy creating things and explaining things to make them replicable. I’d bet most issues in project delivery are due to poor handover practices. Someone told me that’s one of the reasons why doctors have incredibly long shifts: to reduce the number of handoffs. I’ve witnessed this issue in SaaS projects when the upstream team is working with an 𝐎𝐩𝐭-𝐈𝐧 approach (i.e. someone must actively provide some form of approval to proceed to the next step)…But the downstream team is working with an 𝐎𝐩𝐭-𝐎𝐮𝐭 approach (i.e. the workflow will proceed unless there is a specific request to stop it). 👉 Moral of the story: to improve project quality, start by ensuring the teams align on handoff practices.  🧩

I've interviewed 250+ people in my career.Here are five unconventional interview tips you will not find in an HBR article. 👇️1. Get yourself a good mic. We can deal with poor image quality but not with poor audio.2. Each role requires a different skill set. But as a foundation, you need to demonstrate two things: Decision Making and Problem Solving.3. Create a library of 15 stories. Identify the top five skills for the role, and then find three examples for each in your career.4. Practice delivering each of your stories in 3-4 minutes. If an answer takes more than 4 minutes, it's too long.5. At the end, when we ask if you have any questions, the most powerful question you can ask is: Is there anything you've heard today that makes you hesitant about my candidacy? I'd love the opportunity to address it.Click [+ Follow] for more🧩

I was today old when I learned that coffee doesn’t give you energy but instead, it “blocks” the sensation of drowsiness 🤯Our bodies produce a chemical called Adenosine during the day. The higher the level, the more tired we feel. Coffee blocks the receptors in our brain that “measure” Adenosine levels. So you are still tired, just don’t realize it. 🧩

Fun fact I learned today: To collect taxes, King Christian IV of Denmark asked ships' captains to estimate the value of their cargo.The estimate was applied as the tax base without further audit. To my startup friends, 𝐡𝐨𝐰 𝐛𝐢𝐠 𝐜𝐚𝐧 𝐚 𝐭𝐞𝐚𝐦 𝐠𝐨 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡𝐨𝐮𝐭 𝐥𝐨𝐬𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐜𝐨𝐡𝐞𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧?When a new individual joins a team, the system's complexity increases considerably.This is because the number of relationships between team members grows exponentially.The number of possible relationships (R) in any group of n persons (like your team) is [n x (n-1) / 2].This tendency is one of the critical reasons that massive expansion is so challenging to manage.There are more communication challenges, more outcomes to manage, and more incentives to consider when there are more people.I've witnessed it three times in my career when the company I worked for expanded rapidly.And, in my experience, it's all too easy to misjudge the rate at which the team's complexity grows.Consider the birth of a third kid: when a family grows from four to five individuals, the number of relationships almost doubles, from six to ten.If you want to learn more, check out Metcalfe's and Brooks' laws. 🧩Click [+ Follow] for more

The perception of progress is as important as the progress itself, especially when managing up. I was on a call yesterday where someone was asked to deliver something - anything - by a very tight timeline. It reminded me of the 𝐒𝐦𝐚𝐥𝐥 𝐀𝐫𝐞𝐚 𝐇𝐲𝐩𝐨𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐬𝐢𝐬, which states that people striving toward a goal exhibit greater motivation when they direct their attention to whichever is smaller—their accumulated or remaining progress.Basically, at the beginning of a project, focus on the accumulated progress (20% complete instead of the 80% remaining) to keep momentum. But towards the end of the project, shift focus on the 20% remaining, as it is more motivating than the 80% completed. 👉 Focusing on small areas 𝐜𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐭𝐞𝐬 𝐚𝐧 𝐢𝐥𝐥𝐮𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐨𝐟 𝐟𝐚𝐬𝐭 𝐩𝐫𝐨𝐠𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐬.🧩Click [+ Follow] for more

Have you heard about Chesterton's Fence?It's the idea that we shouldn't take a fence down unless we know why it was put there 👇When new leaders are appointed, it's common to see the new team redesign how to do things. Their mandate is to change things up. The downside is that in the attempt to fix what's not working, we might change things that did work very well without realizing it. It's tempting to think that the people who built them weren't as smart or didn’t see things in the right way. What's your tomato today? 🍅Let's say you are growing tomatoes to sell them at the farmers’ market. You prepare the soil, plant the seeds and tend to your crop.The day before the farmer's market, a hail storm destroys your harvest. It's just bad luck or perhaps a lack of preparation. Regardless, you won't be able to bring a single tomato to the market. And no one will pay any money just for the work you put in. 👉 The moral of the story is that Effort and Performance are not synonymous. Yet, sometimes they get conflated.It's tempting to book a meeting, write an email, prepare a deck (or tend to your crop) and consider that an accomplishment. But booking the meeting is not the goal (nor is watering your plants).Delivering the business outcome is the goal. For example, selling tomatoes at the farmers' market.   Or driving adoption. Or improving customer experience.So, what's your tomato today?🧩Click [+ Follow] for more

Hire for attitude, train for skills has become ubiquitous. It sounds great, and I like it a lot. And I implement it with moderation. Hiring a team solely based on attitude won't generally allow you to deliver results fast enough. It would help if you had people who - in addition to the right attitude - have also been in the trenches, can hit the ground running, and teach the ropes to the rest of the team. On the other side, hiring solely based on skill will likely not generate enough innovation in the long term. Your practice could become stale, irrelevant and ineffective over time - unable to see new paradigms and take advantage of new opportunities. I believe that if you want to build a resilient team, you need to develop a diverse bench, with both highly skilled seasoned professionals as well as people with less domain expertise but with a lot of potential.A good rule of thumb for the team ratio is 2/3 established talent and 1/3 emerging talent. What has been your experience?🧩Click [+ Follow] for more

Step into the discomfort of transparency.I wrote those words in my yearly planning document in January 2017. Re-reading that statement five years later, I realize the approach has stood the test of time for me, and it has become one of my principles.In 2017, transparency meant publishing my team's project priorities and selection criteria, among other things. That level of transparency would lead to uncomfortable discussions with stakeholders whose projects didn't make the cut.Today, transparency means articulating the individual deliverables required to achieve a milestone and being ready to deal with that level of accountability.It also means asking my team for honest feedback when I know we still have issues. It means not being defensive but genuinely appreciative of those who dare to speak up.It means believing that the only way to get better is to talk about problems with candour and kindness.🧩Click [+ Follow] for more

Contrarian view: the more time I spend hiring, the less importance I give to the resumes.From my Theory of Constraints classes and Lean Six Sigma courses, I remember that we should move the bottleneck as early as possible in the process we are considering.For example, if we are going on a hike with five friends, we want the slowest friend to be in front and lead the group. Only in this way we'll all arrive at our destination together.Resumes can provide insight into the Skill level and relevant experience, but Values-fit and Culture-fit are the absolute deal-breakers. So why don't we assess for Values and Culture first (the bottleneck) and then review the resumes for any candidate that passed? Maybe we could flip the standard hiring process upside down: 1:1 interviews first, resumes screening second.What do you think?🧩 Click [+ Follow] for more

Declining a candidate is the worst part of the hiring process. Here are a few things I've learned along the way:👇• Take the time you need, but notify them as soon as you decide. Don't wait for the automated message to be sent once the job posting is archived.• A rejection email is enough if the candidate only invested 15 minutes in a 1:1 interview. They earned a courtesy phone call if they made it to the panel interview.• Don't offer false hope to soften the blow or feel better. Instead, make the message clear and final. This graph shows the monthly number of people quitting their jobs (provided by the US federal government) since January 2011.The trend line shows that the number of people quitting their jobs has climbed since 2011. The exception is when it dropped significantly in March and April 2020 (Covid). The data is right back to where it would be if the earlier trend had just continued (i.e. if there had been no pandemic).So, an accurate headline such as:“Record number of Americans are quitting their jobs” could also be accurately rewritten as: “Number of Americans quitting their job each month has steadily increased over the past ten years.”🧩Click [+ Follow] for more

Have you heard of Guy Kawasaki's Shopping Center Test for recruiting?He is Apple's former Chief Software Evangelist and now a successful entrepreneur.The test works like this. After the panel interview, you are in the shopping center, and you see the job candidate at a distance, but they have not yet seen you. There are several possible reactions at this point:• You go straight over there to say, Hello! How are you? I'm glad you had the interview. I hope you join our company!• The second reaction is making eye contact and saying, Hello.• The third reaction is thinking that you need to get out and drive to another shopping mall.Unless you have the first reaction, don't hire that person.Check the comments for the original video.🧩~~~PS: Get the free guide at EffectiveHiring [dot] carrd [dot] com

The * perceived * risk of a structured hiring approach is that it can take time. So I understand the appeal of skipping a few steps to speed it up.But in my experience, it doesn't lead to better outcomes or faster execution.To ensure both Speed AND Quality, hiring needs to be your number one priority until you have filled the positions. In practical terms, that means clearing your calendar for a few weeks. My target is to hire based on a ~80 minutes time commitment from the candidate over two to three weeks. That is a 5-10 mins behavioural survey, 15 mins phone interview, and 60 mins panel interview.I'd bet that's faster than the vast majority of hiring managers without a structured approach. 🧩~~~PS: Get the free guide at  www [dot] EffectiveHiring [dot] guide

So start there, give it your best shot and then start preparing for future hiring rounds. → If you have concluded the selection process but have not made an offer yet, hit pause and ask yourself: Is the candidate the right fit for the role or were they just a slightly better choice, in a weak applicants’ pool?If you are not convinced they are the right choice, start over. There is still time to get the right person.🧩~~~PS: Get the free guide at EffectiveHiring [dot] carrd [dot] com

Have you ever heard of Price's law?It states that 50% of the results will be achieved by the square root of the total group in any productive community. Thus, if 25 authors write 100 papers, five will have contributed 50 papers.Another way to think about it is in terms of the 80/20 Rule: 80% of 80% (64%) comes from 20% of 20% (4%). Not exactly the same values, but close. The point is that output generation is not linear.From a recruiting perspective, this shows that the cost of a wrong hire is so high – and the benefits of a great hire are so disproportionate...– that even marginal improvements to the hiring approach will deliver sizeable benefits to your team and the organization.🧩

And aside from performance, employees shape the culture of any company and make it what it is. 🎯 That's why recruiting is the most important thing organizations do, and effective hiring is the most important management practice.Critically, most new managers don't learn how to hire effectively. And seasoned managers take time to become good at it because hiring doesn't happen often enough. 💡 To address this gap, I developed a targeted one-hour course to share all the strategies that the best managers use to assemble high-performing teams.I'm offering a 40% discount to the first 10 participants for answering a few questions, which will help me gather feedback on the material.To take advantage of the pre-launch offer, check the comments or visit: 👉 www [dot] EffectiveHiring [dot] guide 👈🧩
