#FabiosHiringGuide, Step 6.4 - Use a standard onboarding checklistIf you read this far, you made it! This is the last step in my Hiring Guide.The last piece of a good onboarding process is a checklist of all the tasks to complete in the first six weeks. The list includes administrative (i.e. access to systems, networks, and buildings) and operational (i.e. review team rules, roles & responsibilities, and work processes) tasks.Three main actors are accountable for completing tasks during the onboarding phase: the Hiring Manager, the New Hire, and the Buddy.✅ The Hiring Manager will own tasks such as providing the assets (e.g. laptop, phone, etc.), reviewing the team's rules, and clarifying performance expectations.✅ The New Hire owns tasks such as booking 1:1 with their peers and reviewing onboarding documentation.✅ The Buddy owns tasks such as inviting the New Hire to shadow all the meetings for the following two weeks and adding the new team member to relevant group chats.🧩

#FabiosHiringGuide, Step 6.3 - Send the welcome letterOne component of the standard onboarding process is a welcome letter to the candidate, sent shortly after the offer is formally accepted.The letter sets expectations and identifies the next steps in the onboarding process.  Check the pdf guide linked in the Featured section of my profile for a template. In the meanwhile, here is an example:📧 Hi Emily,I’m excited to have you join the team! Here’s some info you might find helpful:The start date is officially [date]. I will book a weekly touchpoint between now and then to review this onboarding deck [link]. We have assigned you a “buddy” to help direct you in the first few weeks. Your buddy is [Name], and you have met her during the panel interview.Once you join, I’ll ask you to book 1:1s meetings with all your peers to get to know each other.Things are in constant flux, but at this stage, I don’t expect to have any project assigned to you until [date]. So during this time, I’ll ask you to shadow your buddy.I’ve submitted a request to give you access to the main platforms we support. You should receive the details in the next few days.Can you please send me a headshot and a brief bio? They will be included in the communication I’ll send in the next few days. Welcome aboard! 🧩

#FabiosHiringGuide, Step 6.2 - Assign a buddyThere are so many things to learn when joining a new team. While we will always be available for questions, we can't cover everything ourselves. So we assign a buddy.The buddy has three primary responsibilities:1️⃣ They will be the new hire's first point of contact for any question regarding the role and our department, and the company at large. 2️⃣ They will invite the new hire to shadow all their meetings for the first couple of weeks.3️⃣ They will book a weekly 1:1 meeting for the first three months to answer any questions or check in on the new hire's progress.I try to match the right buddy based on personality, experience, and available capacity. It's helpful for the new hire to have a peer guiding them through the first few weeks. And it's an excellent opportunity for the buddy to practice and demonstrate leadership and coaching skills.🧩
Coming soon 😃

#FabiosHiringGuide, Step 6.1 - Create an onboarding planThe purpose of an onboarding plan is to ensure the new hire is effective within a few weeks instead of months.It includes things like:• Team rules• Meetings with peers, extended team, and partners• Roles and responsibilities• Work processes and methodologies• Key objectives and performance expectations• Suggested training and certifications• Access to documentation repositories • Inclusion in distribution listsIt's impossible to create a template given onboarding is so specific to the role and the company.But in the pdf guide linked in the Featured section of my profile, you will find the first few slides of the onboarding deck I have used for some time.🧩

#FabiosHiringGuide, Step 6.0 - Onboard the successful candidateCongratulations! You've put in a lot of effort and have hired a new team member. And you are both very excited about getting to work together.But all that effort and excitement are wasted if the new hire cannot take on assignments quickly. So don't drop the ball now!The onboarding process and the first few weeks are critical to the new team member's long-term success and performance. The purpose of a standard onboarding process is • early effectiveness • so it's not just about getting access to emails and various systems.Designing and creating an Onboarding Strategy is a fascinating topic and deserves its own practical guide, (maybe a future series), but here is a summary of the steps I follow:1. Create an onboarding plan2. Assign a buddy3. Send the welcome letter4. Use an onboarding checklist🧩

#FabiosHiringGuide, Step 5.5 - Decline a candidate via voicemail (bonus step)Declining a candidate via voicemail seems harsh, eh? Maybe. But in my experience, it is still better than playing phone tag for an entire day. The few times I've had to do it, the candidates were appreciative. I generally make two phone calls attempts within a few minutes. If the candidate doesn't pick up the phone the second time, I leave a voicemail.Here's how it might sound: ☎️ Hi Emily, it's Fabio.I'm calling to let you know that we will not be proceeding with your candidacy at this time. I know that's hard to hear in a voicemail, but I thought it was better to give you the information quickly rather than risk playing phone tag or sending an email. You have a lot to offer, and the entire panel was very impressed by your interview. It was a tough choice, but I have decided to go ahead with someone else who I think was a better fit for the role.I'm happy to talk more if you wish. For now, I wish you all the best in your search. 🧩

“The large, positive correlation between speaking time and leader emergence is well established.” This is known as the Babble Effect. I respect Adam Grant and for once, I disagree with his recommendation. The solution is not to “stop rewarding people for dominating the discussion.” The data clearly shows that we do! (whether it’s right or wrong). A better approach is for competent introverts to speak up more. 📣Good leaders might learn from Adam’s message and change how they facilitate their team’s discussions, but that’s not a reliable solution. Competent #introverts should dare to speak up (an action within their control) rather than rely on the chance of having a good leader (an external factor outside of their control). #SundaySelfReflection🧩
Hey #Toronto! Do you know an interior designer looking to join the hottest design firm around? 🔥#interiordesigner #hiring

#FabiosHiringGuide, Step 5.4 - Provide feedback to a declined candidateHiring is a tough choice. It's often a subtle choice. The distinctions between candidates are a matter of degrees. It's not as simple as one person is good, and the other is not.Therefore, providing feedback is tricky.I generally try to offer some feedback and ask the candidates if they are interested in hearing it. I find it's a small way to compensate for their time spent going through the interviews.To do that, I pick 2-3 pieces of relevant feedback I have written down during the debrief with the panel members. And then, I start my sentences with, During the interview, you did not demonstrate...I generally get two reactions:Some candidates are open and genuinely grateful to get some feedback.Others don't want to hear it or challenge it in non-constructive ways. In which case, I know I made the right choice.🧩

#FabiosHiringGuide, Step 5.3 - Decline a candidateAssuming your top candidate has formally accepted the offer, you can start declining other candidates.I don't believe we can decline a candidate via email after a panel interview. I think we owe them a phone call. This is how it might sound:☎️ Hi Emily, it's Fabio.I'm calling to let you know that we will not be proceeding with your candidacy at this time. You have a lot to offer, and the panel was very impressed by your interview. It was a tough choice, but I have decided to go ahead with someone else who I think was a better fit for the role. I wanted to give you the information as soon as possible. It was nice meeting you, and I wish you all the best in your search.  🧩

TELUS Business folks, I need your help! I'm looking for a dynamic Senior Business Analyst to join our team.If you are familiar with the TELUS Business organization, its Wireline business processes and have experience with the Odyssey Order Flow, I'm looking for you! 👋Our mandate is to drive the adoption of the new Odyssey functionalities built by our IT delivery partners. We work closely with business stakeholders to ensure engagement during the project phases. Job posting is going live soon, but send me a private message if you are interested or know someone who might.  📢 Spread the voice! Like, comment, share.#hiring @ TELUS

#FabiosHiringGuide, Step 5.2 - Negotiate with your candidateIn my experience, there is little room for changes once the offer has gone through a Company's internal approval process. If this does not reflect your reality or your room for negotiation, that's awesome!For the rest of us in a similar situation, my approach is to do my due diligence and work with the Talent Acquisition Consultant to make a fair and competitive first offer. But what if the candidate comes back asking for more, and you are unlikely to get the offer changed?Well, you can compellingly present the overall compensation package beyond salary and bonus. To do this, you need to learn about your company's Health and Wellness initiatives, paid time off, share purchase plans, learning & development opportunities, discount programs, and other perks.Check the pdf guide in the Featured section in my profile for a list to get you started.And consider adding a dollar value next to each item to the extent possible. 🧩

#FabiosHiringGuide, Step 5.1 - Make a job offer to the top candidatePlease, do not have HR or your Talent Acquisition partner present the offer. Do not miss this rare opportunity to build a bond with your candidate. The offer is presented over the phone - not via voicemail or email - by the hiring manager - not by a delegate. This is how it might sound:☎️ Hi Emily, it's Fabio.I'm calling to make you an offer because I'd love for you to work for my team!You'll receive the formal letter from HR, but I wanted to talk to you first. The position, as we discussed, is [role title]. It's is a full-time position starting on [date].The compensation package is $X + Y% performance bonus. So, this is the summary. You'll receive a formal letter later today from HR. If you have any questions, I'm glad to address them now. If I cannot address them, we'll get them answered. My phone number is 000-000-0000.I'd like to have an answer by [date]. I'm eager to get the onboarding process started!🧩

#FabiosHiringGuide, Step 5.0 - Communicate your decisionCommunicating your decision after the panel interview means delivering both good and bad news to the candidates. These are the steps I suggest:1. Make a job offer to the top candidate2. Negotiate with your candidate3. Decline other candidates4. Provide feedback to a declined candidateWhile the steps are pretty straightforward, the how is important. So this week, I'll share more details about each of these steps.🧩

These are dark days. It’s impossible to support the illusion of normality when such political and human tragedies occur.Today’s message from Adam Grant is so timely. It makes me think about the many examples of poor leadership we see worldwide. And the few great ones. And reflect on what I can do in my little patch of land to keep chaos at bay. I think it starts with rewarding those that dare to speak up.#SundaySelfReflection🧩

#FabiosHiringGuide, Step 4.6 - Check past work referencesChecking past work references is often seen as a formality. I did. Until years ago, I made a terribly wrong hire that I could have prevented with a quick phone call. Finally, I've learnt the lesson.During the interview process, you must obtain consent from the applicant to contact their references and ask employment-related questions. That's why we ask for it early in the process, at the beginning of our first phone interview.We don't let candidates choose their references, but we ask them to speak to the people who supervised them. It is good practice to talk to two or three work-related references.Your Talent Acquisition Partner will be able to provide a list of suitable questions, but some examples are:• Please describe your working relationship with the Candidate? (ensure they led the candidate)• How would you best describe the Candidate's ability to handle change and ambiguity?• Would you rehire the Candidate again in the future? 🧩

#FabiosHiringGuide, Step 4.5 - Debrief with the panelIn my opinion, there is little value in having a panel interview without taking the time to hear the feedback from the panel members.Here's how to go about it:After the interview - during the break before the debrief - each panel member sends the hiring manager a ✅ Hire / ❌ No Hire recommendation via private message. This. Is. Important. Don't start the debrief until everyone has provided their recommendation.During the debrief session, every panel member presents their rationale and evaluation on the three main criteria identified in step #4.1: Interpersonal, Culture fit, and Skills.You can use the Candidate Tracking tool from step #2.1 to record the recommendations of each panel member.Ultimately the decision sits with the hiring manager. However, in my experience, the recommendation from the panel is often unanimous, in one direction or the other. Occasionally a panel member has a different opinion from the majority, which we can discuss during the debriefing. If the panel is split between Hire / No Hire, I suggest proceeding with extreme caution. One of the challenges to consider is that panel members will not feel accountable for the success of a colleague they wouldn't have hired in the first place.🧩
“in pursuit of love and adventure.” It sounds like a life well lived 👏

#FabiosHiringGuide, Step 4.4 - Host the panel interviewIn my experience, providing the candidates a consistent interview experience helps with the accuracy of our selection. In addition, a standard approach reduces the number of variables and increases the fairness of the whole process.Here's how to go about it:✅ Introduce the panel to the candidate. Briefly introduce the members of the panel and their role in relation to the position (e.g. colleagues, stakeholders, or partners). ✅ Review the steps of the interview process. Please explain what the process looks like, which phase we are in and what comes next. State that the last step will be checking past work references, as already mentioned in the phone interview.✅ Ask the same questions to all candidates. We also ask them in the same order, so we can compare their answers.✅ Take lots of notes. In my experience, this helps to keep focused and to evaluate the clarity of the answers in real-time.Check out the pdf guide in the Featured section of my profile for a script you can use to kick off the panel interview.🧩

#FabiosHiringGuide, Step 4.3 - Organize the panel interviewI've attended many interviews that were 60 minutes long, used up until the very last second, and then everyone had to join their next call without any opportunity to discuss the candidate.My recommendation is to book 90 minutes with the panel members. The meeting will include 60 minutes with the candidate, a 5 minutes break, and 25 minutes debrief for the panel members.A helpful tip is to book two separate but overlapping meetings: 1️⃣ one 60 mins meeting with the candidate 2️⃣ and a 90 mins meeting with the panel membersHere some more details:1️⃣ In the meeting invite for the candidate, I include three items:• Overview of the panel interview format• Link to a helpful article about behavioral questions• Request for samples of past work2️⃣ In the meeting invite for the panel, I include four items:• Candidate resume• Samples of relevant work provided by the candidate• List of 10-12 predefined behavioral questions• A reminder of the interview structure and purposeCheck out the pdf guide in the Featured section of my profile for the meeting invite template.🧩

#FabiosHiringGuide, Step 4.2 - Questions for the panel interviewBehavioural questions are the most effective systematic form of interview evaluation. We ask them to learn how a candidate would respond to a specific workplace situation and solve problems to achieve a successful outcome.They are not really questions but rather invitations to reflect on past experiences. They might sound like this:☑️ Right decisions are sometimes unpopular. Tell me about a time when you made a decision that wasn't popular, and explain how you implemented it successfully.They follow this format: the Context (right decisions are unpopular), the Invitation (Tell me), and the Desired Behaviour (how you implemented it successfully). There are hundreds of questions online to get you inspired. You can use this format to create 10-12 questions. While some questions can apply to any role, I'd offer that the best ones are targeting specific behaviours required by the position, which you have identified in the Job Description and the Behavioural Target (steps 1.1 and 1.2).🧩

#FabiosHiringGuide, Step 4.1 - Purpose and structure of the panel interviewI think it's important to clarify the purpose of the panel interview because I used to believe that the goal was to hire a candidate...Instead, the actual goal is to identify all candidates who meet our standards. And among those, we'll hire the best one. If no candidate in the pool clears our threshold, we won't hire from that pool.The panel comprises the hiring manager, plus 2-4 peers of the successful candidate (i.e. people in the same role). Of course, you could invite a critical stakeholder as well.We ask 10-12 behavioral questions during the panel, customized to the role we are hiring for and defined in advance. They are the same for all candidates, and we always ask them in the same order.We evaluate the candidate on three main criteria: • Interpersonal, or how well did they interact with the group• Culture fit, or how well would they work in our team• Skills, or do they have the technical and soft skills to do the jobTomorrow we'll discuss what makes good questions to ask during the panel interview.🧩

I like this quote. It expresses a lot of the lean and continuous improvement philosophy I admire. I would add that “best” is a moving target, based on external validation over which we have no control. “Better” instead is about a known baseline, based on internal validation and within our control. #SundaySelfReflection🧩

#FabiosHiringGuide, Step 4.0 - Conduct the panel interviewsWhen a candidate clears the phone screen, we move them to the next step, the panel interview. These are the steps I use in my hiring process:1. Clarify the purpose of the interview2. Ask behavioral questions3. Organize the panel interview4. Host the panel interview 5. Debrief with panel and gather feedback6. Check past work referencesNext week I'll share more details about each of these steps.🧩

#FabiosHiringGuide, Step 3.4 - Explain the hiring process during the phone interviewAs we wrap up this week about the phone screen, I wanted to mention one more thing.The phone interview is also the opportunity to review the milestones of your hiring process so that candidates know what step they are in and what might be next. Here's how it may sound:Hi Emily, [greetings, etc.]. Before I ask you my first question, I want to explain how this process generally works. This phone interview is our first step, and it will only be 15 minutes long. So I'll only ask you 2-3 questions, but I may probe and interrupt for more information. The next step in the process - should we get there - will be a one-hour panel interview with me, other team members, and stakeholders. I'll ask you to provide a few examples of your previous work before the panel interview.The last step will be checking past work references. I'll ask you for the contacts of 2-3 former managers, and I will be calling them to ask a few questions about your past roles.I plan on selecting a successful candidate within the next couple of weeks. Ready to begin? Why don't you start by telling me more about yourself?🧩

#FabiosHiringGuide, Step 3.3 - Request samples of relevant workIf a candidate didn't pass the phone interview, we would immediately notify them (i.e. within 24 hours). Check the pdf guide in the Featured section of my profile for some email templates to communicate your decision.Instead, if a candidate makes it to the next step (i.e. the panel interview), we'll ask them to provide 2-3 samples of actual work. Work examples are helpful to get a sense of how candidates operate and whether they have the skills required in the role.The hiring manager will share the samples with the panel members before the interview. The panel members will review the documents in advance and discuss them during the debriefing after the panel interview. Work samples don't need to be directly relevant to the role in question (although it would be better). For example, they could include a presentation the candidates created, a particularly substantive memo, a proposal, or anything they've produced that would give a sense of their work.🧩

#FabiosHiringGuide, Step 3.2 - What to look for during a phone screenAs a general rule, good answers are precise and detailed. When someone has solved a problem first-hand, they can describe it in very minute details.In contrast, weak answers are generic and high level. They sound like a textbook and lack the details of a real-life example.So what behaviors do we look for during a phone interview?✅ For the Tell me about yourself question, we want to see if the candidate can tell a coherent story of their experience and journey. Is the story clear or confusing? Can they describe their experiences in relation to the job they are applying to, or are the links poorly articulated?✅ For the Difficult business decision question, we want to see if the candidate had a straightforward decision process. For example, did they develop multiple options and weigh them against each other with clear criteria, or was their assessment superficial?✅ For the Toughest business problem question, we are looking for a structured approach to problem-solving. For example, did they have a strategy, collaborate with others, and learn anything from that experience?Tomorrow I'll share one last question to ask the candidate after the phone screen but before the panel interview.🧩

#FabiosHiringGuide, Step 3.1 - What to ask during a phone screeningSo we said the purpose of the phone interview is to screen for culture fit, decision-making, and problem-solving abilities. But how do we go about that? While no question is infallible, these three questions are helpful in my experience:✅ Tell me about yourself The goal of this question is to infer Culture fit.✅ Tell me about a difficult business decision you had to make. What were your options, and how did you decide between them? The goal of this question is to infer Decision-making skills.✅ Tell me about the most difficult business problem you had to solve in your career. What was your problem-solving approach? The goal of this question is to infer Problem-solving abilities.Tomorrow I'll share more details about what a good answer sounds like.🧩

#FabiosHiringGuide, Step 3.0 - Conduct the phone interviewsThe phone screen is our first contact with the candidate, and the primary purpose is to identify any red flags. I used to book 30 minutes for a phone interview. However, recently I have found that 15 minutes are enough for me to decide whether to proceed to the next steps or not. During the phone call, we are looking to validate three attributes:• Culture fit: We look for candidates that are a good fit for our company and team culture as a prerequisite for success in the organization• Decision making: We look for candidates who make sound decisions so that we can trust them and delegate to them• Problem-solving abilities: We look for candidates that can find solutions to problems they have never encountered before (because they will)If we don't identify any red flags, we can bring the candidate to the panel interview. Tomorrow I'll share more details about what specific questions to ask.🧩
Another gem from Adam Grant for some Sunday self-reflection. If you don’t follow him already, his feed is an endless goldmine of wisdom.

#FabiosHiringGuide, Step 2.3 - Organize your calendar in advanceSpeed is of the essence during the hiring process. Therefore, we need to be organized to ensure quick execution. Here are a few tactics that worked for me:✅ Reserve daily timeslots for Phone Screens in your calendar:• Book daily placeholders in your calendar (e.g. every day from 9:30 to 10am), then invite candidates based on their availability. You can conduct two phone screens in 30 minutes (15 mins each)• If, like me, you detest the email back-and-forth with candidates to find a suitable timeslot, check Calendly out. This online appointment scheduling tool is free for an individual user with basic needs.• Use the email templates provided in the pdf guide to streamline the booking of appointments (see the Featured section of my profile)✅ Book daily Panel Interview placeholders in advance for you and the panel members:• Book the daily placeholders meetings for the next 2-3 weeks and send them to the members of the panel • What worked well for me was to have the daily placeholders start/end always at the same time (e.g. Monday to Friday, always 3:30 to 5:00 pm)• Update the meeting details with the candidate’s resume once the interview is confirmed• Delete the placeholder as soon as you know that you won't bring a candidate to the panel that day🧩

#FabiosHiringGuide, Step 2.2 - Scan resumesScanning (and then ranking) tens of multiple-pages resumes can be challenging. One effective way to approach this task is to identify in advance what are the key attributes and characteristics you are looking for in a candidate. Then look for them in the resumes and score them for each candidate (e.g. High, Medium, or Low match to requirements). Some key attributes could be:• Behavioural assessment results• Relevant roles and experience • Relevant certificationsEach attribute should have a weight proportionate to its importance in a specific position (see the second row in the screenshot). For example, for particular roles, Certifications are essential and should be given more relevance. In other positions, Relevant Experience is more important.You can use the first tab of the Candidate Tracking tool I shared in Step 2.1 to keep track of all the applicants' scores.🧩

To the fellow people-leaders in my network, take 90 seconds to watch this video. I haven't met Dane, but this short message truly resonated.The crisis of meaning happens at the low point of the change journey, when we have all the information about how challenging it will be, and we need to ask ourselves, am I in or am I out?Leaders' conversations at this point are critical to determining whether people will opt-in or opt-out. Three critical conversations are the Clarity conversation, the Competence conversation, and the Recognition conversation. I.e. Does your team have clarity? Do they feel they have the skills and knowledge to succeed? Are their efforts seen and appreciated?

#FabiosHiringGuide, Step 2.1 - Tracking CandidatesOnce the Job Posting gets posted online, the next step is to track applications. If you manage 5-6 applications for one role, you might not need a system to track them all. But if you are generating a lot of interest or hiring for multiple positions simultaneously, you might have to deal with 50+ applications, in which case you do need a system. Over the years, I have developed this Candidate Tracking tool to help streamline the tracking of each candidate at the different stages of the selection process: CV scanning, Phone screening, Panel interview and Reference checking.If you are hiring right now, you might find this helpful. The file contains a link to the original spreadsheet version too.🧩

#FabiosHiringGuide, Step 2.0 - Manage applicationsNow that the Job Posting is live and attracting candidates, how do you manage the applications? Over the years, I have identified these three steps:1. Track your candidates on a spreadsheet2. Scan resumes for critical info3. Organize your calendar in advanceFollow for the next step or check out the Practical guide to effective hiring for new managers under the Featured section of my profile for more step-by-step guidance and templates.🧩

#FabiosHiringGuide - Step 1.4We can confidently write the Job Posting now that we have a job description (step 1.1) and a behavioural target (step 1.2). The job posting should include the top responsibilities identified in the job description and the target behaviours indicated by the behavioural target profile. For example, a job posting designed to attract suitable candidates to a customer-facing role will include terms such as Informal, Extraverted, Rapid decision-making, and Flexible leadership. Instead, a job posting designed to attract the best profile for a data migration project will include terms such as Disciplined, Thorough, Methodical, Ability to follow established policies and procedures.By including the appropriate language, descriptors and behaviours, we will maximize the chances that people with the right profile apply for the position.🧩

I have been coaching a couple of team members recently about preparing for an upcoming job interview. Here’s the best way I’ve found:• Make a list of the five most essential skills required to succeed on the job. Sometimes you can infer them from the job posting, but I suggest you talk to the hiring manager and other stakeholders. • For each skill, think about three different examples from your careers that demonstrate competence in that domain. • Practice describing each of these 15 scenarios in under 4 minutes following the CAR format (Context, Action, Result).🧩

#FabiosHiringGuide - Step 1.3 continuedIf you are #recruiting but do not have access to behavioral assessment software, you can use the DISC framework. You can *sort-of* guess people's personalities by observing the following characteristics:• Do they tend to speak and act more quickly or energetically than others? Or are they more calm and methodical? The answer can help identify where they sit on the Fast vs. Moderate Pace scale.• When under stress, do they get frustrated that things aren't happening fast enough and spin between options? Or get more time to analyze even more info and build consensus? The answer can help you guess the position on the Task vs. People scale.I find this approach helpful if you have been working with someone for some time. In the context of a hiring decision instead, it is far from perfect, and I’m sharing it just in case you don’t have a better option. 👉 Check out the •free• guide on Effective #Hiring under the Featured section of my profile for more detailed step-by-step guidance. 🧩

#FabiosHiringGuide - Step 1.3What if you are #recruiting for a role but do not have access to behavioral assessment software?If your organization doesn't provide a behavioral assessment tool, you should, first of all, advocate for it. In the short term, though, you can use the DISC framework. DISC classifies behavior into four types (Dominance, Influence, Steadiness, and Conscientiousness) by looking at people's preferences on two scales: • Task versus People. • Fast-Paced versus Moderate-Paced.👉 Effective #hiring is an essential #management practice. Check out the free guide under the Featured section of my profile for more templates and examples.🧩

#FabiosHiringGuide - Step 1.2Building a behavioural target profile is an *essential* step in the interview and selection process. Hiring managers at most companies can leverage behavioural assessment software which provides a valuable additional data point when assessing a candidate's fit for the role. You can work with your Talent Acquisition partner to select an existing target profile or create a new one based on the activities you consider an essential or frequent part of the job.There are several providers on the market. I've had the most success with Predictive Index Behavioural Assessment: an untimed, free-choice stimulus-response tool that measures a person's motivating drives and needs. Look it up. You can take a free assessment online and decide for yourself if it’s accurate. 👉 Effective #recruiting is an essential #management practice. Check out the •free• guide on Effective #Hiring under the Featured section of my profile for more detailed step-by-step guidance.🧩

#FabiosHiringGuide - Step 1.1When #recruiting, you will be tempted to write the job posting immediately. However, a better way is to take a moment to write a job description.A Job Description is different from a Job Posting because it is not for external distribution. Instead, it contains the role’s top 10 responsibilities.An excellent approach to get started is to email 3-5 people who are familiar with the role and ask them to complete the following statements:• The reason the company created this job is [blank]• The most important ways people in the role should spend their time are [blank]• The 2-3 most important duties of this job are [blank]• What this job takes to be successful is [blank]• The most straightforward way to see if this job is done well is [blank]👉 Check out the •free• guide on Effective #Hiring under the Featured section of my profile for more templates and examples.🧩

You might have heard the saying, “Knowledge is power.” It’s not a wrong model, but it is imperfect. My experience has been that “Action is power” is a better principle. A thought for the weekend, for those with an analytical mind and that battle too often with “analysis-paralysis.”

Do you have a job #interview coming up? Here are three things you can do to improve your odds instantly:• Learn about Behavioural Questions. What they are. How they sound. How to answer them. Then practice delivering your response in under three to four minutes. If your answers are not structured and concise, it’s a red flag. • Get a *wired* headset with a noise-cancelling microphone. It’s less than $30. It doesn’t look as cool as wireless earbuds, but the sound is crystal clear, and you won’t run out of battery halfway or sound echoey in a small room. If we don’t hear you properly, we *might* tell you once, but at that point, you might not be able to do much. And we are not telling you a second time. You just showed five people a lack of planning skills. • The first question is always “Tell us about yourself”. A good answer gives us a sense of who you are as a person, not only as a professional. We are not looking for a summary of your CV, even less of your current role. So practice your elevator’s pitch and start the interview strong. If you seem surprised by the question or tentative in your answer, you wasted the opportunity to make a great first impression. #nowhiring #careers

If you are #hiring, you *need* to include a behavioral assessment in your arsenal. Whether it's DISC or something more sophisticated.A natural fit for the role is essential to performance and job satisfaction.

Are you looking to increase your productivity? The single most effective tool I've personally encountered is the Pomodoro Technique.In a nutshell, it's a time-boxing technique where you work for 25 minutes, then pause for 5 minutes. And every 4 Pomodoro (i.e. 2 hours), you take a 15 minutes break (instead of 5 minutes).There is more to it, but this is the condensed version. I discovered it in 2011, during an intensive MBA program, and it dramatically increased my output. I distinctly remember studying for 8 hours straight the first time I used it, without getting tired or losing focus. I was hooked.More than ten years later, I consistently go back to it when I have a lot of deliverables and little time. Check out Francesco Cirillo to learn more.
Insightful. What are YOU waiting for?Thanks for sharing, Peter Yang 🙏

I learned today that there are three different temperature scales (°C - °F - °K) because they measure values in reference to different things.The Celsius scale is about water: 0°C is where water freezes, 100°C where it boils, and liquid water exists in-between.The Fahrenheit scale is based on human beings: 0°F is where you risk serious injury without insulating equipment, and 100°F is where damage can occur without proper cooling.The Kelvin scale is based on the Absolute Zero. So 0°K is as cold as it can get according to the laws of physics, and anything else is more heat than that.So they are based on Water (°C), Humans (°F) and Physics (°K) 🤯#FabiosFunFacts

January 2019. Three years ago, my then team gathered in Vancouver to attend a 3-day PI Planning session with other 40+ team members. Remember when you could travel and pack a lot of people in a room for three days?We already worked remotely from across the country, so meeting in person was a rare occurrence. We took the opportunity for some fun team-building activities and some yearly planning.I was meeting some of them for the first time after working together for seven years (eh, Nika?). Others were officially joining my team that same week (what a start, Andrew Scott and Monica!). It was such a diverse team, with roles spanning from Sr Technology Architect to Sr Strategy Manager, from Business Analyst to Communication Manager. Our mandate was to identify and prepare the handful of projects that would be part of the next 12-week delivery cycle, among hundreds of submissions. We didn't make many friends at the time.Those were my Systems Strategy and Planning days. My world was about Scaled Agile, Project Intake Process, Funnel Management, Fact-Based Prioritization, Business Value Score calculations, Delivery Outlooks and Benefits Realization reporting. I remember the hard work as we advanced the Strategy and Planning practice, figuring out how to implement Scaled Agile in our reality. Eventually, our approach would be described by a third-party assessment as the internal benchmark for transparency of estimations (cost) and prioritization (value, capacity). Other significant accomplishments included balancing a marshmallow on a spaghetti tower 😜But mostly, I remember learning from and being inspired by these people's intelligence, work ethic, perseverance and talent. Thanks for the laughs, the lessons and the memories Nika, Dora, Jackie, Monica, ASR, Chris and Mark. Truly a memorable experience and a great team! 👌#ThrowbackThursday

Are you an (aspiring) entrepreneur or intrapreneur? If yes, I invite you to watch Guy Kawasaki's top 10 pieces of advice about entrepreneurship. The video is called The Art of the Start @ TiECon 2006. Google it. It's insightful and funny. A gem, in my opinion. I remember watching it 15 years ago. I found it again recently, and it's still relevant. He was Apple's chief software evangelist and became a successful author and venture capitalist. Here's a quick summary of his speech. Check the comments for the timestamped links to each section 👌1️⃣ Make Meaning (4:25)The best reason to start a company is to make meaning, and there are three ways to do it:- Increase the quality of life- Right a wrong- Prevent the end of something good2️⃣ Make a Mantra for your organization (6:20)A mantra is *not* a mission statement. Here are three examples: - Wendy = Healthy Fast Food- FedEx = Peace of Mind- Nike = Authentic Athletic Performance 3️⃣ Get Going (12:10)Three keys to getting going:- Think different - Polarize people - Find a few soulmates 4️⃣ Define a Business Model (14:55)A key step some companies forget- Be specific- Keep it simple (costs $1, sells $5, 20% gross margin)- Ask women about your business model5️⃣ Weave a MAT (17:15)A new company is a blank sheet of paper, which makes it hard to prioritize- Milestone, e.g. Finish design (vs Order stationary)- Assumption, e.g. How many sales calls/day- Task, e.g. Rent an office6️⃣ Niche thyself (19:55)Create a matrix. Aim to be on the top right corner.- (Y-axis) Ability to provide unique product/service - (X-axis) Value to customer - Other corners are Dotcom, Price and Stupid7️⃣ Follow the 10/20/30 rule (24:15)When giving a presentation to investors or stakeholders- 10 slides- 20 minutes- 30 point font size8️⃣ Hire infected people (27:25)When hiring, don't consider only background and education- Ignore the irrelevant- Hire better than yourself- Apply the shopping centre test9️⃣ Lower barriers to adoption (30:15)There are three ways to lower barriers to adoption- Flatten the learning curve- Don't ask people to do something that you wouldn't- Embrace your evangelists🔟 Seed the clouds (31:45)This point is about rain making and sales- Let a hundred flowers blossom (embrace the early adopters, even if they are not who you intended to)- Enable test drives- Find the influencers#️⃣ Bonus - Don't let the bozos grind you down (33:40)

Do you know how much available capacity your team has to take on new projects? Here's how to find out in a few minutes.Understanding and communicating your team capacity/availability is top of mind if you are involved with project delivery. So last year I created this spreadsheet to estimate my team's capacity. While not perfect, it proved pretty helpful in forecasting the ebbs and flows of our bandwidth.My team is moving to an online project management tool, and I thought I'd share the 2022 version of the file for those that might need it.This file is not supposed to be perfectly accurate. Instead, it provides a weekly forecast of available capacity *at a glance*. I prioritized ease of use over accuracy because I think the margin of error in these estimates is pretty high anyway. I'll include a link in the comments if you want to give it a try for your team. To start using the file, you will need to copy the original. Go on to the top left, click File > Make a copyHere's a quick overview of how it works:- Row 1 shows the weekly schedule for the year. The current week automatically shows in yellow, so you can easily identify it. The Q1 weeks are coloured in gray, Q2 in blue etc.- Row 3 shows the average team allocation. It estimates the overall capacity of your team for each given week. It simply calculates the average of all the team members' allocation in the spreadsheet. - Row 5 shows the individual team member allocation based on the different projects they support. For example, there are 15 team members in the file with up to 10 projects each (not shown in the screenshot).- When you enter your team member's name in cell A5, it will automatically populate in the rows below. How I use it:- I ask my team to enter their own estimated allocation at the beginning of each week. They enter the % allocation in the relevant cells for the entire project duration if possible. If not, I ask for a five weeks forecast.- These numbers can change from week to week, so I don't use them as commitments but rather as best guesses. Again, I'm prioritizing timeliness over accuracy.- I briefly review the estimates every one or two weeks during the recurring 1:1s to better understand the status- For example, looking at the forecast in the screenshot, you can tell that this team member will have a peak of work at the end of February and that they will likely be available to support another significant project only as of the week of March 14 (when their estimated time allocation drops to 60%).That's it in a nutshell. I hope it can be helpful. If you have less than 15 direct reports, you'll need to change the formula on Row 3 to calculate the average correctly. Add a comment below if you need some help to do that. If any of you spreadsheet gurus have ideas on improving it or automating it more, please go ahead and share the love.

Have you ever heard of Self-Determination theory? The term self-determination refers to a person's own ability to manage themselves, make confident choices, and think on their own. The key idea is that three innate and universal psychological needs drive people and that personal well-being is a direct function of the satisfaction of these basic psychological needs: Autonomy, Competence, and Belonging. I recently had the chance to talk about my team's engagement, and I referred to this theory as one of my guiding principles in managing people since I learned about it several years ago.• AutonomyIt is about leveraging individual talents, avoiding micromanagement and getting out of the way. It also means being tolerant of mistakes and allowing people the time to fix their errors: individuals who are not terrified of making mistakes will accelerate their learning curve. • CompetenceIt is about providing clear guidelines about the expected deliverables and then upskilling for any gaps. A clear path to career progression is also an element of developing competence: this can be achieved by clearly identifying the skills and level of proficiency required to achieve the following role/title.• BelongingIt is about fostering a team culture of business performance and lightheartedness. I've read somewhere that camaraderie results from sharing pain (i.e. hard work and failures) and laughter. I've found that to be true. In my opinion, fostering a sense of belonging starts early, like including peers during the hiring process and asking for a commitment to team values during the onboarding phase.

The World's least affordable cities to buy a home. Vancouver and Toronto make it into the Top 10,  2nd and 6th respectively.A few caveats: these figures are from 2019Q3 and published in 2020; they include ~300 major metropolitan areas across mainly the US and Commonwealth.A city's house affordability is calculated by taking the median (the middle number in a sorted list of numbers) housing price and dividing it by the median household income. So if I understand this correctly, it would take a median-income family 11.9 times their entire after-tax income to buy a median house in Vancouver (8.6 in Toronto). According to StatsCan, the median after-tax income of a couple with children was $105,500 in 2019.

It's the time of the year to write performance reviews (if you haven't done it already). Over the years, I've put together a few tools to help with this critical task. The topic would deserve a much longer post, but here's the summary in case it can help those going through it right now:• In a spreadsheet, list all the dimensions you will use to rate performance in the first column. I have identified about 20, and here are some examples: Decision Making. Problem Solving. Communication. Relationships. Quality of Work. Volume of Work.• In the other columns, write the team members' names. Then for each performance dimension, assign a value. I use a 5-point Likert scale, from Very High to Very Low. Although I do have a good sense of each individual's performance, I find this step helps articulate what I already know more precisely.• Next step is to write the review. I generally write a Core Message first, which is the one thing I want the team member to remember. Then I elaborate with more comments following the SEER format (Summarize, Elaborate, Example, Restate), for example, Amy is my best strategy manager. She consistently exceeds every standard. She recently got approval for a project we struggled with for months. She's an example we should put on training videos.• To help me with the exact language, I've used a few books like Phrases for effective performance reviews when drafting the message. Those sentences are great templates that I can refine to communicate what I want to convey more effectively and professionally.Again, this summary barely scratches the surface of this critical and timely topic. If you are willing to share, I'm curious to hear about how others go about it and what has worked well for you.

The fresh start effect refers to the human tendency to take action towards a goal after a special occasion or key date has passed. For example, New Year's Day, or the first day of the month. Or a Monday. These points in time turn out to be good mental triggers for us to get started. I was recently reading that one way to get more triggers to start fresh is to split your day into multiple segments (e.g., morning, afternoon, evening). So if you missed the opportunity to do something, the following trigger is just a few hours away. For example, you had a bad morning? It doesn't have to ruin the entire day, and you can start fresh in the afternoon.I'm going to try this out.

In Naples, Italy, the mayor announced a ban on fireworks for a second straight New Year’s Eve. This was the response from the citizens. I can’t help but find it entertaining. I’ve never been a fan of fireworks, the high risk of injuries, and the impact they have on domestic animals and wildlife. At the same time, I understand that, after a couple of years of collective sacrifices, there was no chance people would miss the opportunity to celebrate the New Year as loudly as possible. While New Year’s fireworks and Naples are almost synonymous in Italy, we’ve seen similar forms of defiant behavior in other European countries, from Berlin to the Netherlands. I wonder if it speaks to the number of impositions people can tolerate before resorting to disobedience.
Happy New Year, folks! 😃

The World economy is estimated to be $94 trillion by the International Monetary Fund. The United States represents about a quarter of it, with China and Japan coming second and third. Canada is 9th. It’s an interesting view, although imperfect. For example, it doesn’t consider the population size (aka GDP per Capita). In this case, the three European tax heaves of Monaco, Liechtenstein, and Luxembourg take the podium, the US is 9th and Canada 24th. Also, it doesn’t consider “what can you buy for $1?” or the purchasing power parity (aka GDP PPP), in which case China tops the list, the US is 2nd and Canada is 15th. All these rankings made me think about the effect of increased productivity on a country's GDP. If productivity increases, I now use fewer resources to produce the same output. Which means I can sell at a lower price for the same profit. But if I reduce the price, doesn’t the GDP go down? If so, an increase in productivity could theoretically see a reduction in GDP? If not, why not? Is it because of the increased sales volumes driven by the lower prices?I should probably take it easy with the eggnog. 😜
It’s not.

I get the irony of posting this on LinkedIn. It still rings true. After countless delays over the past few years, the James Webb Space Telescope is set to launch this Christmas weekend.It's going to orbit at 1.5 million km from Earth. For comparison, the Hubble telescope orbits at 570 km and the Moon at 384,000 km. Those distances are hard to comprehend. If you convert them into time to make it easier to grasp (1 km = 1 sec), Hubble is 9.5 minutes away, the Moon is 4.5 days away, and the James Webb will be 17 days away 🤯The development started in 1996, a collaboration between NASA, the European Space Agency, and the Canadian Space Agency. So it has been in the making for 25 years, and it is arguably one of the most complex things humanity has ever built. It will see the first light ever produced after the Big Bang and the formation of the first stars and galaxies, effectively working as a time machine. It will detect chemical signatures on other planets, allowing scientists to look for life and assess a planet's habitability. It will watch the birthplaces of stars and might help us understand why stars form in clusters and how planets form around a star.This telescope will rewrite science textbooks over the next several years and possibly our perception of life as it reveals more information about the Universe's origins. I'm excited to witness this engineering feat and inspired by the story of curiosity, ingenuity, and perseverance it tells 🚀🛰️🛸

Do you make new year's resolutions?I used to, then stopped. I’m still divided. But this list below sounds like a great starting point. It got me thinking about what each of these means to me:• Entrepreneur’s mind. It means taking accountability for anything that happens. Thinking in terms of “maybe” and “and” instead of “no” and “either/or.” Focusing on execution over strategy. Learning constantly. • Athlete’s body. It means eating healthy and exercising daily. Being in bed by 10 pm and sleeping 8-hours a night. Stretching and meditating. Fasting and getting cold exposure. • Artist’s soul. It means being open to experiences and finding opportunities to use your creativity. Trusting your instinct, even if you can't precisely articulate what it is that you are doing. Being authentic. If you don’t know James Clear, he is the author of  Atomic Habits.

This week, I wanted to squeeze in as many phone interviews as possible (I'm #hiring a Sr BA) but quickly realized that it would have taken me too much back and forth with the different candidates to find a suitable timeslot for each.#Lean Management would consider this #Waste because this step of the appointment booking process is not adding any value (to the Customer, or anyone involved for that matter).So, after the second back and forth this morning, I invested 45 minutes in learning about #Calendly and setting it up for what I needed. This online appointment scheduling tool is free for an individual user with basic needs.After the initial configuration, I sent a link to the candidates and asked them to book the timeslot that best suited their availability. Boom. All other meetings got booked without any extra email exchanges. Loved it!If you are in a similar situation and detest the email back and forth to find a timeslot, check Calendly out.

I understand there can be “right-click” replicas of any image. But that’s been the case for any artistic artifact since the dawn of time. It’s no different than an actual Picasso painting vs a fake one. They look identical, but one is worth millions while the other doesn’t. If Picasso released his last painting as an NFT, wouldn’t you be able to tell (through blockchain technology) that he was the original issuer? Sure, you can flood the market with replicas of a Picasso painting, but you can rest assured that anyone able and willing to pay millions will make sure to buy the one that tracks back to the original owner. I’m curious about NFT but want to poke holes to see if they hold water. So I’m genuinely interested in understanding the weaknesses (I’m sure there are), but so far, these arguments have not convinced me that these are fatal flaws.

Do you know what a #unicorn startup is?It’s a privately-owned new company valued at over $1 billion. And the term Unicorn originates from the venture capital industry.#Startups are companies in the early stages of operations and typically lack adequate financial resources to move onto the next phase which is why they look for capital from venture capitalists. Well, there are more than 800 unicorns globally, and these 35 are the biggest, each valued at more than $10 Billion as of December 2021. Although you might not recognize #ByteDance - the biggest of them all, valued at $140B - you probably have heard of their product, the video network platform #TikTok. For comparison, Volkswagen, the 3rd largest automotive group by capitalization, after Tesla and Toyota, has a $130B market cap. 🤯So there’s that...

Italy 🇮🇹 has been named Country of the Year by The Economist 🥳 The award goes not to the richest or the happiest but to the one that improved the most.You may not know that after football ⚽, complaining about #Italy is the second biggest national sport. So I was pleasantly surprised to learn that the recognition was awarded not for the prowess of its footballers, who won #Europe's big trophy, nor its pop stars, who won the Eurovision Song Contest, but for its #politics. 🤯The Economist describes premier Mario Draghi (also a former president of the European Central Bank) as a competent, internationally respected prime minister.In addition, Italy's vaccination rate was among the highest in Europe while its economy is recovering more speedily than those of France or Germany.As an emigrant, I've started to look at Italy from afar, with the eyes of a foreigner. As a result, I grew more intolerant of its absurdities and more appreciative of its blessings. Today, I'm pleased to celebrate the gifts.

An interesting whitepaper from Gartner about the future of work. In a nutshell, Hybrid Work is here to stay, and organizations need to rethink their workforce models to remain resilient. Here are the key takeaways (I'll put a link in the comments):1️⃣ Hybrid workforce strategies are here to stay. Work will not go back to normal.2️⃣ Employees thrive when given radical flexibility. They are not less productive when remote.3️⃣ The best driver for innovation is intentional collaboration, not serendipity (aka water cooler moments).4️⃣ Hybrid work doesn't apply only to knowledge workers. There are options for retail employees, field technicians and other on-site personnel. 5️⃣ Hybrid work does not dilute the corporate culture. On the contrary, remote/hybrid employees report higher culture satisfaction.For my friends who are or manage on-site personnel (#4), some options include: providing employees with the choice to schedule and trade their hours; allowing them to work at different locations; providing the choice of when to start/end each workday; adjusting schedules as needed (i.e. four 10-hour days instead of five 8-hour days); authorizing remote work when not on site.Worth a read. Link in the comments.

Like many, I was fascinated by Strategy when I joined the workforce. I thought Strategy drove the business. I thought Strategy was the source of everything else. So I invested time reading about it, going to business school, analyzing business problems to ensure I could recommend the absolute best option possible.As I gained more professional and life experience, I've shifted my perspective, and I've come to believe the following:• Strategy is a continuum. What the director calls a strategy is a tactic to the CXO. And what's a tactic for the director is a strategy to the marketing specialist.• The value of Strategy is in the thinking, not in the plan. It’s in the knowledge and understanding you acquire while analyzing facts, data, and trends about the world and about your organization. • Execution drives Strategy, not vice-versa. It's a secret that only a few management consultants admit, behind closed doors. Your company's capabilities, skillsets, and culture will determine which strategy you can choose. The best strategy is the one that your organization can execute. Otherwise, it's just an expensive deck.

How big can a team become and still be cohesive?Every time a new person joins a team, the complexity in the system grows significantly. That's because the number of relationships amongst team members increases geometrically. Basically, in any group of n people (like your team), the number of possible relationships (R) is [ n x (n-1) / 2 ]. This phenomenon is one of the main reasons it's so tricky to manage tremendous growth.  More people means more communication issues, more outcomes to manage, and more incentives to consider. I've seen it first hand three times in my career when the group I was part of grew rapidly. And in my experience, it's easy to underestimate the rate at which complexity increases as the team expands. Outside the business world, think about the birth of a third child. When the family goes from 4 to 5 members, relationships almost double from 6 to 10.  Agile's ideal team size is famously set based on the two-pizza rule, which states that no squad should be so large that two pizzas can't feed the whole group. That's about eight people or 28 relationships. Check out Metcalfe's and Brooks's laws if you are curious to learn more.

Have you heard of #NFTs?Gartner (see my post from a couple of days ago) says that companies quickly recognize the potential of non-fungible tokens (NFTs) to grow business models and drive new revenue streams. And that by 2026, non-fungible tokens will propel a new entrant into the top 10 highest-valued companies.I've been reading about NFTs recently, and it is a technology that certainly will revolutionize many industries. Yet, I found it difficult to explain it quickly. Then I found this video. Tom Bilyeu explained to Quentin Tarantino how to use non-fungible tokens with his cult movie Pulp Fiction. Watch it to learn what's an NFT in 60 seconds.So NFTs are about:• Ownership: the same way an original Picasso is worth more than a copy. Blockchain technology allows for tracking of the lineage and guarantees originality.• Status: the same way people buy luxury brands like Gucci or Ferrari, to communicate Status. A public wallet of the NFTs owned will allow communicating Status at a distance and to a larger audience.• Belonging: communities develop around artists, fictional characters, games, and more. NFTs will allow people to identify each other and join large or exclusive groups and events. • Value Storage: imagine if the Beatles released 500 NFTs of their debut song's artwork (Love Me Do, 1962), let's say to raise funds amongst their early fans. How much do you think that would be worth today?There are inflated expectations around this technology today. As a result, not all current NFT projects will be successful. As the Internet's dot-com bubble in the 1990s, the vast majority will ultimately fail. But as with the Internet, some will win big (Amazon-style), and the underlying technology is here to stay.

Have you heard we live in a VUCA world?Google it. In a nutshell, it means that Volatility, Uncertainty, Complexity and Ambiguity make it challenging to understand the current situation and predict the outcomes of specific actions.Change Management, therefore, is the arena where companies, departments and individuals battle the VUCA world. There are several helpful Change frameworks, and what I like about the Knoster model is that it shows the importance of every element needed for success.For an overview of Change Management models, check out the excellent article titled Change Management: The 10 Best Approaches & Models on Sergio Caredda's blog.

December 2015. Six years ago this week, we celebrated the year-end with the Montreal chapter of our CRM Enablement team. Thanks, Google Photos, for the reminder.Those were my Marketing Automation days. I worked with Intake Briefs, Campaign Flows, Call-to-Actions, Leads, Routing Rules, Preference Centers, and CASL Anti-Spam regulations. Occasionally I also attended lengthy meetings about which critter was more suited to the campaign. Maybe one too many.The most memorable moments include several iPhone launch campaigns preceded by hectic long days. There may or may not have been a situation where a routing rule got accidentally deleted by a well-meaning team member, and I had to call Veneranda at 5 am to save the day. Unfortunately, to this day, we have not been able to identify the culprit.The most rewarding project was successfully migrating our Marketing Automation platform from Eloqua to Salesforce Marketing Cloud. It was a 12-months long project that went from evaluating different MA platforms to conducting a multi-dimensional assessment of the three alternatives, from presenting our recommendations to our Director and the management team to managing the project of migrating the platform. I'm sure Bogdan lost a few nights' sleep towards the end.I remember the hard work as we advanced the Marketing Automation practice, achieved industry-leading turn-around times and consistently achieved excellent CSAT scores of >95%.But mostly, I remember the camaraderie, the laughs, and the selfless teamwork. Thanks for the memories Veneranda, Isabelle, Bogdan, Brian (who I think was taking the picture), and Steve.#ThrowbackThursday

A step-by-step playbook for the Business Analysts practice (built with my team).• Developing a team culture that I'm proud of: well, this is not my achievement but my team's, since culture is mostly emerging when growing at a high pace. Although I've seen how you can help shape it by creating clear expectations about values, relationships and results.

Step into the discomfort of transparencyI wrote those words in my yearly planning document in January 2017, my first at TELUS. Re-reading that statement almost 5 years later, I realize the approach has stood the test of time for me, and it has become one of my principles.In 2017, transparency meant publishing my team's project priorities and selection criteria, among other things. That level of transparency would lead to uncomfortable discussions with stakeholders whose project didn't make the cut...Today, transparency means articulating the individual deliverables that are required to achieve a milestone, and be ready to deal with that level of accountability... But it also means asking my team for honest feedback, when I know we still have issues. It means not being defensive, but instead truly appreciative of those who have the courage to speak up.It means believing that the only way to get better is to honestly talk about problems, with candor and kindness.
Did you know why Bullish and Bearish markets are called this way? 🤯
Are you polite or kind?Good reminder that politeness alone is not a good long term solution. And that you can be honest and truthful, while still being kind.

Feeling the Sunday blues? The practice of Gratitude helps with mental well-being apparently because it trains the Reticular Activating System (RAS) in the brain. One of the most common occurrences of RAS is when you buy a new car. Once you buy that car, you start noticing more cars just like yours on the road.In the same way, if we can learn to focus on the good in ourselves and in our situation, we prime our Reticular Activating System to pay attention to what is positive and in return RAS helps us notice more things that are good.What are you grateful for about your week?___👇 Hit Like if this is useful, and share with your network

Unpopular opinion: I recently had a discussion about the concept of Minimum Viable Product (MVP). For years I've had an instinctual dislike for the idea of MVP, but wasn't quite sure why.Now I think it's because it's diametrically opposed to my own values.1) I want to over-deliver on value to my Customers 2) I want to build something that's future-proof3) Above all, I want to be proud of my workIn order to deliver a Minimum Viable Product, you have to forgo all three. I fully support the spirit of agile which generated the idea of MVP: start small, quick prototyping, continue iterations, maximum learning with minimum effort etc.In my experience, too often MVP is about delivering just enough so that you don’t get kicked out of the door. I don't stand by that.

Hey Linkedin, when was the last time you hired for attitude rather than skills? Was it a success story?“Hire for attitude, train for skills” has become a pretty ubiquitous saying. It sounds great, I like it a lot. And I implement it with moderation. Hiring a team exclusively based on attitude (assuming you can accurately assess it) won’t generally allow you to deliver results fast enough. You need people who have been in the trenches, can hit the ground running and can teach the ropes to the rest of the team. On the other side, hiring exclusively based on skill will likely not generate enough innovation in the long term. Your practice could become stale, irrelevant and ineffective over time - unable to see new paradigms and take advantage of new opportunities. It has been my experience and it is my belief that if you want to build a resilient team, you need to build a diverse bench, with both highly skilled seasoned professionals as well as people with less domain expertise but with lot of potential (i.e. they are a good culture fit, demonstrate a strong work ethic, have a growth-mindset and are coachable). The ideal composition would depend on complexity of the skills to be acquired, on the need for early results, and on team size, among other factors - but I’d say a good rule of thumb for the team ratio is 2/3 skilled professionals and 1/3 people with potential. What has been your experience? I'd be interested in your thoughts on this topic if you are willing to share them below.#Business #Management #HumanResources

Have you heard of the #GreatResignation? Here’s an alternative perspective worth considering. The Great Resignation is the ongoing trend of employees voluntarily leaving their jobs, from spring 2021 to the present, largely in the United States.Here’s the interesting viewpoint: the graph shows the monthly number of people quitting their jobs (provided by the US federal government), since January 2011.What this graph and trend line show, is that the number of people quitting their jobs has been climbing since 2011. The exception to this is when it dropped a large amount in March and April 2020 (COVID). The data is basically right back to where it would be if the earlier trend had just continued (if there had been no pandemic).So a headline such as “Record number of Americans are quitting their jobs” could also be written as “Number of Americans quitting their job each month has steadily increased over the past 10 years”Check out Mark Graban for more on this insightful and though-provoking angle. #HumanResources #Business #Hiring #FutureOfWork

Literally hours after I have published here on LinkedIn my Practical Guide to Effective #Hiring for first-time managers, this very successful serial entrepreneur (GaryVee anyone?) posted the message below, which seems to be in complete contrast to mine - and it got me thinking.I obviously believe in a well-structured hiring process and I think you can remove most of the guess work from recruiting.That said, I know that no hiring process will generate perfect results 100% of the times. You can follow all the right steps, and still make a bad hire (type 1 error). Or miss the opportunity to hire a superstar (type 2 error), because the system screened them out – or maybe because the process took too long and they accepted another offer. So, make a bad hire or miss a superstar: which one of the two is the biggest error?The benefits of a great hire are so disproportionate that missing the opportunity to hire a superstar is likely the worst of the two. As you can never get that back. You can’t really fix that mistake. On the other side, you can fix a bad hire. And the faster you act, the more contained is the damage. This is how I interpreted Gary's message.#HumanResources#Management#HiringAndPromotion

As a not-so-smart boss myself, I wholeheartedly disagree with this entire Inc. Magazine article. The one sentence I do agree with is that the value people bring “are their ideas. Their creativity. Their analysis. Their willingness to take responsibility and embrace accountability”. For the rest, this is terrible advice, particularly for people who are starting in a new role, a new team or a new company. To begin with, verbal communication famously represents less than half of all communication between individuals. So for a remote workforce desperately looking to cooperate and to bridge distances, cutting off the massive value of non-verbal communication seems unwise. Furthermore, I don't agree with the hidden assumption that you need to perform for the camera. Why can't you just be yourself? Many things once taboo while videoconferencing, are now common and acceptable (e.g. kids sneaking behind their on-camera parents). It’s actually been an incredible tool for sharing our own uniqueness and getting closer to each other. Lastly, one of the points of the article is that people “used to look at you less during in-person meetings” compared to how much they look at you now during online meetings. This seems ludicrous. People did look at you all the time during an in person meeting. I consider myself an introvert, and I understand the appeal of being off-camera. Yet a while ago I made the decision that it was important to keep my camera on at all times, for all meetings. I figured that as we lost the opportunity to connect in person, it was important (1) for my team, my peers and my boss to see me on daily basis and (2) for people that didn’t know me yet, to realize I wasn’t just a faceless voice. When someone joins my team, one of the first things I tell them during our first meeting on their first day, is that in order to be successful they will need to build relationships. In fact, it is part of being on the team and one of the reasons I hired them for. It’s literally a paragraph in the recruitment ad. They are expected to develop relationships with our team, partners and stakeholders. And turning on the webcam is the simplest, most powerful step they can take towards that goal. I invite my team members to keep their camera on during their own meetings because I honestly believe that it’ll help their relationships – and careers – in the long term. I do request them to be on camera during our weekly 1:1s and all-team meetings as it helps me read the room, pick up on non-verbal clues and get a sense of whether my message is landing correctly – all things that I can no longer do in person. I do this because any tiny piece of feedback I can get, helps me generate better outcomes for all.  Turning on the camera is the simplest yet most powerful gesture for a remote workforce to build stronger relationships, connect more deeply with each other and be more successful in their role.#RemoteWorkforce #Career #Meetings #Opinions
